Â¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	On the extraction of blood from the tongue.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX. On the extraction of blood from the tongue.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When the bloodletting is done with medicines as I said in the division of cure and does not work, then look in his throat in front of the sun, or behind it when you press his tongue with the instrument which tells me.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	But if your cough falls on the leech, extract it with a small hook or with subtle movements from the side.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	That if it is not possible with them: then take a closed tube and insert it into his throat as far as the throat; and then introduce into the tube an iron rod heated with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this many times: and let the patient abstain from all water during the day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then let him take a full drink of cold water and open his mouth in it; and let him blow out air from his mouth while drinking it, and not swallow anything: and let him move his hand with the water.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For the leech immediately falls when he feels the water.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	But if he does not go out with it which we have said then smoke the patient with incense, or with an ashe-pot, with an instrument which tells me in smoking.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this many times, for she will fall by herself.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the method of operation in smoking is, that you take a pot, in which there are plums with fire; and the pot is covered with a lid, in which there is a hole; and place the end of the instrument in that hole.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then allow a suffumigation, and let the sick one place his nose at the end of the cannula, and close it, so that the suffumigation does not escape, until you know that the suffumigation has reached the blood-sucker.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the leech quickly dies.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	If it does not fall, then perform many suffumigations.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And let the sick one bear hunger, and eat sauce, and other things, and do not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	Therefore it is necessary that he go out with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the instrument from which the leech is drawn out of the throat when it falls on it and it burns.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is similar to forceps, as you see: but because it has a curved tip that enters the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its end is similar to an ear, which is called cicogna, in which there is a sharp edge of the blade; and when it grasps anything, it does not let go at all.
Â¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	The opening of Aphemata, and their section, and care in general.
Caput XL.	Head 40.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many species of Aphemata, many ways, according to which the memory comes, that is, one, and the same in this book: and they differ in the perforation of them, and in the section of their own from two types.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	Of which one is a species of Aphemata in itself, and because it grasps from the moisture.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second type is because of the places, in which it happens out of the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	For an accident of Aphemata happens in the head, it is different from an accident of Aphemata in the anus; and an accident of Aphemata happens in fleshly place, it is different from an accident of Aphemata in joints; and each has its own judgment according to operation.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And of the Aphemata are those that do not need to be pierced, unless after maturation of blood within them, and completion of it; and of them are those that need to be pierced when they are raw, and do not mature according to the completion.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	As the blisters which are near to the wound.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	Because the blister, if it occurs near the wound and is prolonged, until it becomes rotten what is in its surroundings maybe the ligaments are corroded, or the nerves of that joint: so it is the cause of a closer contraction of that member.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or is the blister on the main limb: for if you delay the piercing of it, until it has ripened, it will harm him or through that main member.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	Or is near a limb, pierce then that immature one: and do not, so you pierce, the raw blister, which has not been completely digested, unless it is near a limb, so that it does not putrefy deeply, and it extends to the insides of the body, and becomes a fistula, or becomes at the edge of it, that does not heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	It is necessary that you know the time for piercing the blister, which has ripened according to the complement: and it is with the sedative of pain, the retreat of fever, and the diminution of redness, and pulsation, and keenness of head of the blister: and the rest of the signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And you shall make the same piercing in the lower place of the blister, and more prominent eminence: and is the piercing to be made in the length of the body, if the blisters are in the parts of the hands and feet, and places of the ligaments, and nerves, and arteries, and up to the last in all equal places, there is no reflection.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	In those which reflect, pierce with the hand of the member.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When however the blister is in the fleshly places: then it is better that you should stop piercing it, until its digestion has been confirmed, as we have said according to the complement.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	Because if you pierce it before that one, the course of the virus will be prolonged from it, and there is much dirt and corruption, and perhaps the lips of it will become harder, and its depth.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And certain staples are to be drilled through according to the breadth of the body, at need; or according to that which the limb requires.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary to make a small drill hole in small staples, and a large drill hole in large staples; or to cut sections of similar sizes of staples.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are staples from which the skin should be sewn; and it is cut when it has already been made like a cloth, and has been completed, that which has already died: like that which happened to many, such as a laceration, and abscesses.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And there are staples that cut in three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And from this one cuts like a fig leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	As the staple of the groin.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And there are staples from which a round section is made, and a lunar section; and similar ones from sections.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	In truth, where there is no head, such as the soft staples, it is necessary to drill him with a superficial drill, or simply flat.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it is necessary, when the staple is thick, and has already gathered a lot of puss, and you drill it, so that it does not break and does not leak all the pus at once: but take off a part from it.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then wrap the staple with cloth until another day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then take out some pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this many times according to the measure, until it comes out: especially if he is a weak person of declining vigor, or a woman expecting, or a small boy, or an old man decrepitous: for the spirit of animals often resolves with the exit of pus: and perhaps the sick one dies, and you do not perceive it.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore take care of this chapter with great caution.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after you have drilled him, when you have drilled these staples, it is necessary to wipe the wound clean: and consider.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If then there is a staple of little wax, or it is a flat section, then administer wax from linen, or an old cot.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	If there is a large abscess and many perforations of the fissures, then you should then insert an awl into all the fissures until they are closed.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	If you have cut off a part of the abscess or have made it around: then you should fill it with old cloth, or as when the skin is tender, or when the hair has grown and there is no moisture: and bind it tightly for three days.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then let him discharge it, and care for that with him as he needs to with ointment, until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	If, however, there is a flow of blood at the time of your operation, then you should administer cold water and vinegar to it after it has been soaked with cloth: and place it often on the site of the bleeding.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	If, however, the bleeding persists, then you should administer a regimen and treatment, and powders, which are recorded in various places in our book of this subject, and with a powder.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	If, however, it is in the season of winter and the site of the abscess is full of nerves: then you should fill the powders with wine and hot oil: and place them on the sites.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is in the season of summer and the places are fleshy: then you should place powders soaked with water and oil, or wine and oil, and all of that cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until the third day, as we have said, then you should let go of the abscess and clean it, and administer to it what is suitable for its treatment, until it heals.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is therefore what is necessary from the knowledge of the treatment of abscesses in general.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the half, however, I have already said about every abscess, which is a path to the treatment of its individual head.
Â¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	On the Section on Abscesses that occur in the Skin of the Head.
Caput XLI.	Head 31.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Abscesses occur on the skin of the head, small ones are made of nodules, which are surrounded by tunica, which are bags, like those from hens' nests.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	There are many types of them.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Of these there are many: and of these there are those that retain moisture similar to lime: and of these there are those that retain moisture similar to mud and pulp: and these are like, and among these are those that are hard rocks.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the cutting of all, and in the extraction thereof there is no fear when you cut at their joints, for there is no difference in the arteries.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation in their cutting is, that you try it out with an instrument, whose form has come after these, which is called the intromitter, until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if that is what contains moisture, then dry it up by cutting it according to the length of the surface section: in this form.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin with the cutting from line b to line a. But when the moisture is emptied out, then peel off the skin that contains that moisture, and do not leave anything of it inside.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For many times it will return if there remains anything of it.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then dip the cloth in Egyptian ointment, if it is present: and if not, in water and salt: and fill it with it, and leave it until another day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For this corrosion will eat up what remains of the skin.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the ointment over the cloth a second time and a third time: and if you bear it well, until you are convinced that nothing remains of the skin, then indeed do not be afraid of the ointment; for I will heal.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	That if an apoplexy contains a swollen nodule: then dry it up according to this form, having a section of the shape of a cross: and throw off the skin between two lobes of the section, and peel it off from all parts: and try your skill in extracting the skin that contains the nodule.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	But if there is a difference to you when the arteries are cut, then do what I will tell you after.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And do likewise in an apoplexy, if it is hard, from the section, and with the same cure, according to what we have said.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And cutting above the stone is easier: for it is little of blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And when there are some of these stones in the head of some men, where there is no moisture within.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	That is: because I followed over the stone in the head of a married woman, and found the stone like a solid and hard, rough, white, which could not be broken: and if it were struck by him when he threw, it wounded himself.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	In others however of these stones of accidents in the head, besides this that happen in the heads of boys, and at the roots of the ears, all of them is a superficial cutting.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or put an incision of them always from their lower part, that it may alleviate the course of blood to the bottom.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then take care of those with him as they should be taken when he is cured.
Â¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	Regarding the cutting of the strumpfes in the neck.
Caput XLII.	Chapter LII. The head.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	These stones often happen in the neck, and under the armpits, and sometimes in all the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And over those that happen from them in the neck, there is one, and many: and they come from within; and all of the strumpfes come out of their own skin, as we have reported.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And the kinds of these strumpfes are many.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	For they are some from stones; and some hold moisture; and some are wicked, and do not submit to the cure.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	In that one that you see of good disposition when it is touched, whose manifest is its nearness to the color of the skin, and which moves to all parts, and does not adhere to the nerves of the neck, nor to the guide-è¡ç®¡, nor to the arteries, and is not deep: let it be cut off with a superficial cutting from the upper part to the lower part of the body in a line, b. to the line, g., and clean it out of all parts: and extend two skin lips with an anchor, or with many anchors, if you can bear it, as we have said in the head strumpfes, and draw them out slowly.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And it is necessary to take great care so that no new wound or nerve occurs.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let the knife be not very acute, lest it cut your hand with an incision, or disturb the sick person, and you fall into a mistake which is unnecessary.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	But if you cut a vein or an artery, or prevents you from performing the operation, then put the piece in a dry place, or some powder that stops the blood, and tighten the tourniquet, and let go of it until the sharpness subsides, and the wound softens: or else it begins to rot.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For the blood is stopped by the bandage. So bring it back to your operation, until you are finished.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then inquire with your index finger, if there is anything left of the staphylitis with some powder: so cut them and clean them.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	For if it is in the root of a staphylococcus a large new one: then it should not be cut from its root: but it should be tied with a strong double knot, and let it fall by itself without doing any harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the wound with old cotton that has already been soaked in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then take care of yourself.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the whole staphylococcus is cut: then you should gather the two edges of the wound: and close it immediately, once you see that there is no dÆ°;
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	If you see that there is dÆ° due to the size of the staphylococcus, then you should consider cutting its root and pulling it out: and administer the suturing that I have described.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And the staphylococcus that contains moisture should be punctured with a superficial puncture: so that you can see the place of maturity of it: and put the puncture away from what follows below the body, as we have said.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then after the puncture administer liniment with ointment and similar things, so that it corrupts what remains from corruption, until such time as you see the wound have healed: then take care of yourself with a generous ointment of meat, until it is cured.
Â¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	On the sectioning of the epiglottis with an accident in the throat.
Caput XLIII.	De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancient ones said that this sectioning of the epiglottis was done by someone, and I do not see anyone in our land who has done it: and this is the writing of their speech.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	In those who have a ÑÐ¸Ð½Ð°Ð½ÑÐ¸Ñ, the section of the epiglottis should be performed: but it is not done by that: for all the air and lung are weak.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	In those who have a hot apostema in the mouth or throat or in both amygdals, when there is no disease in the canal, one should use the section of the epiglottis in order to escape the destruction which is caused by pre-formation.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	Therefore, when we wish to do this, let us cut the epiglottis with a small section under a circle of the epiglottis or four, in that which is between two circles by the quantity, which is a section in a sifac, not in cartilage: and this place is suitable for cutting, because it is separated from flesh, and the blood vessels are far from it.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	That if the doctor is timid, then he should extend the skin of the throat with a hook.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then he will find the skin, until he reaches to the canal: he should stop the flow of blood, if he sees anything from it.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then let him cut the sifac which we have mentioned: and let it be signalled on the section of the canal from the phlegm which comes out from it, with that by which it is interrupted, and by the abruption of the voice.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And let go of the loop at some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	So when the hour is coming near in which fear is caused by pre-formation, let two aggregates of the lip of the wound of the skin move it and leave it alone without cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then administer medicines which make meat grow, until it heals.
Inquit Albucasis.	Says Albucasis.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The summary of this discourse that we have related is an exposition only when it is evident that one of these aphorisms has already been affected by the disease; and the sick person is raised above death, and his thirst is quenched with a desire to breathe: so he is saved from death, and therefore they ordered that the wound should be closed until the malady had spent itself, and it was a malady of three days, and almost the same as himself: then they commanded that the wound should be opened, and that he should be tended until he recovered.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And this which I saw myself is that a servant took a knife and put it into his throat, and it entered with it a part of the canal of the lungs.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was called to cure him, and I found him gasping, as it is the breathing of a dead person.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	I then opened his wound, and I found blood flowing out from the small wound.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	So I was convinced that he had not cut the vein, nor had it burst: and breath came out of the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	Then I closed the wound, and tended to him until he was well: and nothing happened to the servant but a hoarseness in his voice; and after a few days he returned to his usual health.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Therefore, I say that there is no fear in the section of the epiglottis.
Â¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	On the section of the gullet.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter XLVIII.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This aphorism called Hernial gut is a great aphorism, second in order of appearance, and the color of the body: it is found in women very often.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it has two causes: or it is natural; or it is accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	Certainly, there is no talent in the natural.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	But the accidental has two causes: one of which is similar to the nods of the pinguis;
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And the other mode is similar to an aphorism that is made from the contraction of an artery.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And there is fear in it, and it is not right that presumption should be made about it with iron, unless it is little; and you test it, and investigate it with an instrument.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If then you pierce the node with a heavy needle, and it is not suspended with any sutures: then dry the node, as they dry knots; and take it out with what holds it, if it is in a sack: and if not, then examine all of it.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then be careful of the place with what is necessary for curing, until it heals.
Â¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	Â§ On cutting above species of nodes.
Caput XLV.	Ch. L.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many species of nodes, and I have already spoken about them in a division: and it is necessary that I should tell here the difference between node and excision: when making a doubt.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say, then, that where there is excision, there is heat, and fever, and painful throbs, until an efflux of serous fluid subsides, and putrefaction is completed: for then the fever and the heat subside.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	But where there is a node, there is no heat, nor fever, nor pain, and they hold them in a sack of their own, which is second to the color of the body: and it is like beans, and becomes like a mat, and greater or smaller.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And they are according to two species: either they are fat: or they hold moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colors of moisture are many, according to what I said in a division.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	It is necessary, then, when you are treating a node, that you experiment on it, and investigate it with an instrument which is called Intro-mission, according to the form of its shape in the chapter which comes after this.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the way of investigating by penetration, and all nodes is, that you take this instrument, and introduce it into a moistened place, which you pierce in an aposteme: and you move your fingers gradually with it, until you know that the instrument has penetrated the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then take your last hand according to the measurement of the apophelian arch.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then extract the intramuscular and examine what emerges from its groove.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If then there emerges a running moisture, whatever its color: then dry it out by a superficial sectioning, according to what I said regarding the other apophelian arch.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if there does not emerge moisture in the groove of the Intromissum, then you will know that it is thick: so dry out above the area with a sectioning in the form of a cross, according to this very form, as I taught you: and suspend it by means of hooks, and scrape off the skin from all parts with ease: and guard the cruciform section so that you can remove the healthy tissue with the Nodo.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If then the skin is broken during the procedure and it is not possible to remove the healthy tissue, since this often happens, then remove it hastily, until nothing remains of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if there remains of it a little or much, the Nodo returns according to many accounts.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	For if it hurts you, and there remains of it a little: then fill your wound with some acrid powder: and tighten the bandage, and place it over the arch that sits on fire, and take care of the wound with the rest of the cure, until it heals.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If then is a large Nodo, then cut two of its lips, and take care of the wound with that which has become inflamed.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If then is a new, pulsating or not pulsating nodule: then approach it, and fill the place to be cut three times, and leave it bound for two days, or three, until the bandage putrefies and the inflammation subsides: then return to cutting what remains of the Nodo.
Â¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	Regarding instruments from outside for the purpose of sectioning and piercing.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter LXVI. On the head.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	There are three forms of Intromissums:
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	For from these there is great power, and from these there is mediocrity, and from these there is weakness.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	For from iron let there be made a square of four extremities askew, that they may hold fast the entrance to the apotome.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are forms of experimentations, and no, i.e., piercings: and there is one called bers, i.e., piercing: and there are three species.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	For from these there is great power, and mediocrity, and weakness.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They come together, that they may be investigated by the apotomes, and exits, and slits, and pustules from him because he is between them from bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are round, third, smooth, such as the big needles which are made of citrine, or of brass, or of iron, or of silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And better ones are those that are made of citrine.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And there are experiments also of black lead, which come together so that they may be experimented on the slits, whose reflections are caused by their smoothness, so that they reflect with gentleness with those reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And again there are three species.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	For from these there are long ones, and from these mediocrity, and from these brevity, according to the quantity of width of the slit and its strictness.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	Form of the anvil, and they are many species.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	For from these there are simplicity, i.e., those which have one smoothness: and they are three species as you see, Great, Medium, and Small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And from these there are blind anvils: and they are three species.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And from these there are anvils having two smoothings, and they are three species: and from these there are anvils having three smoothings, and they are three species: and all of these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are forms of scalpels, with which they cut and scorch the nodules and apotomes: and they are three species: for from these there is great power, mediocrity, and weakness.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities which are acute, the extremities of others are not acute: and they are not laid on so, except as with them a ligament is made in an excoriation of the nods at the fear of an incision of the vein or nerve: and that it may heal through it the sick, and find a little calm from the bitterness as it finds by an excoriation of pustules.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are Magda, and they are the species of three.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of air, and they are similar to the radio, with which alcohol is made: and in the long end there is a small spot called Oculto: and it runs to the insides, and to the outsides when you see it, like you do.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The shape of the Spatumilium which are hidden between the fingers at the perforation of the pustules: and they cannot be perceived by the sick: and they are of three species, great, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The forms of the Wind-vessels, with which the flow of blood is cut off: and they are of three species, great, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	Let them be made of air, or of yellow brass, round, a little long, like you see it: and let them be to subtility.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And let these species of the Wind-vessels be with you great, and small: that you may cut off blood through them with velocity at need, and then when there is no medicine present with you.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	However, you should not use them for the cutting off of blood in any part of the body, and you should not use them except in the fleshy places: like the lizards of the legs, and of the hips, and of the arms, and of the breasts, and of the foot, and of the groin, and similar to these, from the fleshy lizards, moist.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes they are made small from these, other similar to the corks of the fists, according to their form: which cuts off blood when it flows from a place of phlebotomy, or at an incision of the vein, or artery: and sometimes they are made round according to this form.
Â¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	On the treatment of mammilli in humans which resemble mammilli in women.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter LVII. On the treatment of mammaries in humans which
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	When the mammaries of some men swell up towards the side of sleep (that is, when they begin to be inflamed while sleeping), until they resemble the mammilli of women, and then remain swollen with milk.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Whoever wishes to avoid this (that is, the swelling of the mammaries), should cover them with a lunar cloth, according to this form from the line B to the line G. Then scrub the entire area with a poultice.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Afterwards fill it with a poultice of incurable ointment.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then join the two lips of the wound together with a stitch, and care for it, until it is healed.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If, however, the mammilla turns downward towards the lower part and softens on account of its size, as happens to women: then it is necessary that it be joined in two parts of a similar lunar shape on both sides, each holding the other near its ends, until they are united by a larger line containing the smaller one, according to this form from the line B to the line G. Then scrub the skin which is between the two lips, and remove the poultice, and administer what we have said about the stitch and powders, which is necessary in the treatment, until it is healed.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If, however, you do not wish to incise it as is necessary to incision, on account of trembling or of the flow of blood: then fill it with a poultice immersed in a corrosive ointment, and leave it, until that which remains from the poultice is corroded.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it, until it is healed.
Â¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	Chapter On the perforation of abscesses, which happened during the reign of Titus.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter LVII.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These abscesses which happen during the reign of Titus, are of a hard kind, which contains a sac and from it there issue secrets.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Whatever is contained within these that is wet should be washed with lunar section, in this form, from line b to line g; and so whatever is there in the apomate from the filth, then fill it with old cloth, and leave it until another day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then the cloth should be removed and treated with a suitable ointment for that purpose, until it heals.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the apomate is from the species of nods of the Strophulus, then cut it over it as we have said in the section on Strophulus equal to it.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If however a tendon is stretched out in this way so that it discharges pus, then administer cauterization to it, as we have said before, in what was pre-empted.
Â¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	As for the section of apomatides that occurs due to an artery or a vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLVIII.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an artery bursts and the skin that is above it hardens, often there results a pustule; also occurs to veins, as it does with them, resulting in a pustule and swelling.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is recognized that the apomate and swelling are due to an artery or a vein, are these: because, when the apomate is due to an artery, it is long, aggregated in the depth of the body; and when you feel the apomate of your fingers, you almost hear a whistle.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And what is due to a vein is round, evident on the surface of the body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And the section over this apomate is an error, and especially if it is under the armpits, and groin, and throat, and other places on the body; and it is great indeed.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore, so that it is cured with iron, and whatever is also on the edges, or in the head, it should be cured too.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Over this, then what is on it from the swelling of the opening of an artery, find in the skin in length.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the section with a hook, then the artery: and free it from the tunics until it is detected.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then introduce a hook underneath it, and let it penetrate until it reaches another side, and tighten the artery with double thread in two places, as I have taught you in the extraction of two arteries that are in the temples.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then pierce the place which is between the two ligaments with a sharp instrument, until blood comes out completely, and break up the aphemia.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then administer the cure which generates pus, until the ligaments fall: then treat that with suitable unguents, until it heals.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	That if there is an aphemia due to the section of a vein, then you must hold your hand so that you do not touch it from the aphemia with skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then introduce a hook underneath the place which you held with your hand, and let it penetrate: and let it remain in it a double thread, until you extract it from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then tie up with it the aphemia with a good ligament: as I have told you in the tying of an artery, from its two parts with its two extremities with thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If you are to extract the thread, then introduce a hook with another thread under the aphemia all around the incision of the hook: squeeze, and tighten your threads in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then dry up the aphemia in the middle of it until there is nothing left inside: then cut off the excess skin, and let go what has been tied to it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then put on top of it a little feather which you immersed in wine, and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then administer the cure, which is made with liniments and unguents, until it heals.
Â¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	The aphemia that occurred from a twist of the nerves.
Caput L.	Head.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	As happened to the aphemia in the artery and vein, so it happened to the nerves: which happened from a punch, or from excessive work, and similar: and it happens to them in many places of help, or of heels, and in any place where joints move: and it is a grey aphemia.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	The color is similar to that of the rest of his body, and it is in many positions without pain: and when it is stretched with vehemence, he feels in it a similar stupor of weakness.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And there is no swelling in the depth of the body, but it is under the skin, and it moves itself to all parts, and does not feel in front, nor before, nor behind.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	What is there on the joints, then, that needs to be rubbed with iron?
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps, then, a contraction may happen.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	But in that which is on the head, or forehead, find skin with oil.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If then there is a small swelling, then hold it with tweezers, and cut it off from the root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large, then hang it by a hook, and scrape it off: then take it off, and collect the wound with a stitch: and take care of it, until it heals.
Â¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	Regarding the cutting open of swellings, which occurs in the belly.
Caput LI.	Chapter LI.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	Some people often get a kind of fungus in their bellies, and in the rest of their bodies, which they call 'Fungia', because it resembles fungi.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	The root is subtle, and the head is large, and their lips are wide apart.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And there is a little of it: and there is some that grows very large.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And I have already seen a man, and there were two swellings in his belly, which were more than other things similar to mushrooms; there was no difference between them, white, small-rooted, and their lips were open, and they were projecting, and moisture flowed out of them always.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	I therefore cut them open, and I found in weight one as much as eight ounces, and the other as much as six; and their operation is, that you consider then, if the moist is infirm, and the color of the swellings is white, moist, subtile-rooted: then cut them open with a sharp chisel, and let the cauterization be in your presence on fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For much blood is expelled during the incision; therefore, if the blood beats you, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	If you see the patient pale and frightened by the incision with the iron, then take a thread from lead which has been made slightly irregular, and tie it with the knot that we have spoken of, and let go of him for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add to the string on the lead.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Therefore do not cease to tie the lead, when it is tight in the wound, until it has been cut off and falls by itself without working.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	But if the lead is thick at the root, then there is some fear and trembling in his incision: especially since it is in the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	However, it is possible that you cut off half of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize him so that he does not return.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then take care of the patient until the wound is healed.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And do not suppose that the lead is incised which is of a dark color, few senses, and an appetizing appearance: for it is an apoplectic cancer: and I have come with a reminder of Cancer after this.
Â¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	On the cure of a prominent umbilical hernia.
Caput LII.	Chapter II.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	Hernia can have many causes.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or from a fistula which is above the navel: and comes out of it thin, or of the intestine, according to whether it happens in the other ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from blood that flows from a vein, or from an artery, according to what has been said above.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from a constricted windiness in it.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If, however, it is from a fistula which is above the navel and comes out dirty: then it resembles the color of an apoplectic patient, and is soft, without pain, and appears in various places.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is from the exit of the intestine, then its location is with that which we have spoken about, which is more variable in kind.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	So when you grasp with your fingers, it hides: then it returns, and perhaps there is a sound: and it is greatly magnified at the entrance to the bath, and laborings are heard.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	But if indeed it is because of moisture, it is soft; then it does not hide when you grasp it with your hand, nor does it tighten, nor is any added.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	Which if it is because of blood, then with these signs appears a patch of bruising to turn blue.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	But if it is born of flesh: then it is a bruise, gray, coarse, and it spreads out according to the quantity of one unit.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	But if indeed it is because of warmth, then you feel it soft.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the work on it is this, that you then, if eminence of the umbilical cord is because of blood of an artery, or vein, or warmth: then you must refrain from its cure.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For in it is fear and dread, as I taught you in the chapter where I said about bruises because of an artery and a vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	Which if the eminence of the umbilical cord is because of intestines, or a hernia: then you must order the sick person to hold his breath, and stand upright with his arms outstretched.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then signs with caustics around the umbilical cord throughout.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then order him to lie on his back with your hands under his back.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then with a wisp of tow around the umbilical cord around the spot you marked with caustic.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Then extend a middle strip of cloth to the top, with a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then tie him strongly around the waist with a cord, or with a silk ribbon tightly bound: and let the knot of the binding be unfastened.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the middle strip of cloth that was extended above the ligament.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	But if you should find him already caught by the ligament: then pull out the binding, and insert your finger into his rectum, and push his intestines into his inside: and if you find a hernia, then take it with a hook, and cut off its surplus.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	If, however, the arteries are opposite to each other, or new: then surround it much.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then go on to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles, and introduce into them two strong threads: and introduce into the two needles that you have made around the clot in the form of a cross, which you make to penetrate.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then tighten the clot in four places on the needles: and if you want, remove the needle, and leave the place, until the flesh has rotted out: and it will fall of itself: or cut it off when it has become thin and rotten.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the wound with the ointment, as much as is necessary, until it heals.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	That if eminence of the navel is out of flesh into it, or out of moisture: then you must tighten the clot, as we have said.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And draw out blood, or moisture, which you have injected into it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then take care of the wound with the ointment to harden the place.
Â¶ De cura CANCRI.	Of the treatment of cancer.
Caput LIII.	Chapter LIII.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	Now we have spoken in the division of the species of cancer, and how it is treated with medicines: and to beware of its cure with iron, so that it does not ulcerate: and we have spoken of cancer generated in the womb, and of the care to be taken in its cure.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients say that whenever cancer is in a place where it can be eradicated: such as cancer in the breast, or in the thigh, and similar places, from the body by means of an operation to take out all of it: especially when it is just beginning.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When, however, it has been cut away, and is large, you should not approach it.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	For I cannot heal it by any means: nor did I see anyone else before me who has cured it.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation on it, when it is located as we have said, is, as it were, a cure for disease from black cholera sometimes.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then phlebotomy him himself if the veins are filled with blood.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the sick one with preparation, in which he lies during the operation.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then throw into the cancer the hooks that fit it.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Then cut off the patient from all sides with the blade, following the examination, until nothing remains of his roots: and stop the bleeding, and do not tear him away quickly, but rather squeeze the places, and wipe away the gross blood with your hand, or with whatever is there.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If, however, the blood flow from the incision of an artery or a vein causes you difficulty: then burn the vein, until the blood stops flowing.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the patient with the rest of the cure, until he is healed.
Â¶ De cura Hydropisis.	Of the treatment for hydropsis.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter LIIII.
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	We have already spoken at length about the division of hydropsis into its species and how water is gathered; we will now speak about the signs of each species and how to cure it with medicines.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And that which is cured by means of iron, is not any other species but only a single one: and it does not approach iron for the species timpanitis: nor for the species hyposarcus within the bowels: for that is a mortal illness.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you have already tried to cure this species of hydropsis with medicines and your treatment has not succeeded: then consider the following.
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	For if the sick one already has a weakness that is added to his hydropsis or other weakness besides the hydropsis: such as if he has a cough, or a fluid-like urine, and similar things: then be careful not to treat him with iron: for there is a fear of this.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	But if you see a young person with an excessive amount of vigor, and there is no other illness besides hydropsis: and he is not a boy or an old man: then the mode of operation in him is such that you stand him up straight between your hands, and have someone else press down on his back while he empties his bowels.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	Then take a spike-shaped spoon, shaped like this.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	Take two acute parts, one long and the other sharp at one end like a spike-shaped spoon.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	However, in it there is something that narrows gradually, so that it does not pierce with it while operating up to the intestines, and does not hurt itself.
Deinde considera.	Then consider.
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	For if there is a generation of Hydropisis from the part of the intestines, then it should be extended with a cut from the umbilicus by three fingers' width, towards the lower side directly over the spine.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	But if there is a generation of Hydropisis due to liver disease: then your section from the umbilicus should be three fingers' width.
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.	And if the generation of it is due to the spleen, then your section on the right side: and it should not also be that it is cut at the place that you want to lay sick, so that there do not run into the weak spot fluids.
Deinde perfora cum instrumento cutem totam.	Then pierce with a sharp instrument all the skin.
Deinde intromitte in illam sectionem, et eleua manum tuam cum Spatumili inter cutem, et sifac, quasi tu excories ipsum: et sit quantitas quae excoriatur quantitas unguis, aut circiter ilud.	Then insert into it the section and spread your hand with the spike-shaped spoon under the skin, as if you were scraping it off: and let the amount that is scraped off be a quantity of a nail, or around that spot.
Deinde perfora sifac, donec perueniat Spatumile ad locum uacuum: et est locus aquae.	Then pierce with a needle, until the spike-shaped spoon reaches the empty place: and this is the place of water.
Deinde extrahe ipsum, et intromitte in foramen instrumentum, cuius haec est forma.	Then draw out the flesh, and insert into the hole an instrument like this, which has this shape.
Et est simile cannulae: fit ex argento, aut aere, aut aurichalco, lene, tersum: cui in inferiori parte sui est foramen paruum, et in lateribus eius sunt tria foramina, duo ab una parte, et unum a parte altera: et facia est extremitas eius incisa, secundum modum incisionis calami, sicut uides: in extremitate eius superiore est armilla.	And it is like a tube: it is made of silver, or brass, or gold, smooth, sharp: its lower end has a small hole, and on its sides are three holes, two on one side, and one on the other: and its end should be cut at an angle, as you see in a penknife's end, and there is an armlet on it.
Nam quando instrumentum peruenit ad aquam, tunc ipsa descendit statim super instrumentum, ergo euacua ex aqua in hora quantitatem mediam.	For when the instrument reaches water, then it immediately drops onto the instrument, so that it flows out of water at a middle rate.
Quoniam si tu euacuas ex ea plus quam oportet, in hora fortasse moritur infirmus per resolutionem spiritus sui animalis: aut accidit ei syncopis quae appropinquat morti.	For if you drain too much from it, a sick person may die at a time when his animal spirit is resolved; or he may die of syncope approaching death.
Verum euacua ex ea secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius, et secundum quod significant tibi dispositiones infirmi ex uirtute pulsus eius, et ex bonitate eius.	But drain from it according to the quantity of its power, and according to what I tell you about the dispositions of the nurse from its pulse, and from its goodness.
Deinde extrahe instrumentum, et retine aquam.	Then take out the instrument, and retain the water.
Quod est, quia retinetur statim propter cutem quae retinet foramen quod est super sifac: de quo narraui, ut perfores ipsum secundum illum modum.	That is, because it holds immediately by the skin which holds the orifice which is above the syphons; of which I told you that you should do so and so.
Deinde itera instrumentum die altero, si uides infirmum tolerare illud: et extrahe etiam ex aqua quantitatem paruam.	Then take out the instrument again on the other day, if you see the sick one ØªØ­ÙÙ it well; and also take out from the water the quantity of it which he exhales.
