Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And make the length of the incision as much as two fingers spread out, or about that: and allow to come out as much blood as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then tie it up with a knot, and let it be until it heals.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And now has preceded at the beginning of the book incision of the incisions, and their cauterization.
Â¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	De phlebotomia of two arteries in the times.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	Of the two arteries which are in the two times of phlebotomy, is to the old hemorrhoidal disease: and the salt, and the careful attention: and the course above the flowing blood acute toward the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of phlebotomy is according to what I tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The sick man strings his neck very much, until two veins appear by a visible appearance: and they disclose their pulsations under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	For then are the signs with the caustice.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then wash the skin above the vein toward the top with your index finger, and introduce the scalpel cut underneath, and wash the blood upwards.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut it, as you did with the two veins; and allow the blood to flow according to the quantity of your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then solve the constriction of the wound, and place your finger on one vein an hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then put thereover the cloth and knots, and tighten it with a strong constriction: and let it be until it heals.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And now has preceded at the reminder of them, and their incision, and their extraction at the beginning of the book.
Â¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	De phlebotomia of the front vein after phlebotomy of the head.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The true treatment of venesection is after phlebotomy of the head, for ancient diseases of the face: and for hemicrania, and for redness: and for foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of phlebotomy is according to what I tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The injured man will lean his neck out, until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument called a fossorum.
Cuius haec est forma.	This is its form.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the prominent acme that is in the head of the fossorum on the vein, and strike it with a comb or some other way: and let the blood run according to the quantity that you want.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then solve the puncture wound, and tighten it, until it heals.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And sometimes when it opens with a phlebotomist.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	However, it should not be that the phlebotomist is acute of limb, as are other phlebotomists, but rather of a broad extremity.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And phlebotomize it according to the transversion: since the mouth is nearby: and perhaps in that place the phlebotomist will break when it is thin.
Â¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	Regarding venesection of the veins in two tear-drops.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	However, the treatment of two veins that are in two tear-drops of two eyes, is for the eye from scabies and redness: and a blister in an eye, and ancient diseases of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of phlebotomy of them is that it tightens the injured man's neck with a vein.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then phlebotomize them: and you stand over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And make the phlebotomy according to the transversion a little bit along the length, with a little phlebotomist, and a little width, for there is no flesh in that place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If the phlebotomist is thin of limb, perhaps it will break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let the blood run according to what you need.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And place a cloth over them, and tighten them at night for one hour, and then solve them.
Â¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	On the phlebotomy of the nose.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	But the phlebotomy of the nose is useful for an acute fever and a swift hemorrhage and facial diseases such as a nosebleed and red spots that occur on the face: especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is that it tightens the neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then hold the nose with your left hand and take a fine, long phlebotomy needle; and fix it on the mid-point of the leporium (nasal septum), between that which separates the nose.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Since the vein does not show clearly there, and because the blood begins to flow immediately:
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And you should keep your hand with the needle moving slightly: and make the blood run out according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then tie it up for one night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For she will recover quickly.
Â¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	On the phlebotomy of the nose and eyes.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	But of the two phlebotomies of Guideius there is a difference: one is for constricting the hot flux, and the incipiency of leprous diseases, melancholic affections, impetigo, and bad sores, and corrosive ulcerations, that is to say, venesections.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of these phlebotomies is that it tightens the neck with a ligature on each side: and let the workman stand over the sick person's head, and let the sick person sit on a chair.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then take a wide phlebotomy needle of the same length as the nose to be phlebotomized.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then extract a measured amount of blood, or according to what you see is necessary for that.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do the same for the other nose.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then loosen the ligature and squeeze two veins together, so that there is no constriction of the sick person.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And let him go until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	He will be cured.
Â¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	On phlebotomy by Albucasis.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	But the phlebotomy of Al-Ghabiri is a means to bring about drunkenness in the mouth and corruption of the tongue; and bad sores; and cracks of the lips, and also those bad sores which are in the nose and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is that you make the sick person sit before you; and tighten his neck with a strap.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then turn the lips of the person; and look at the two veins; one is on the right side of the lip, and the other is on the left side of it; and the indication of both is by the color of amber.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And this is true: because there are small veins around them, black.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	So cut one of them with the other one.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	But if there is doubt about you, and you don't know which of them is which; then turn to the incision that is bigger than them, and more apparent.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And also make the same thing with the two veins that are in the upper lip: and much more, because custom is used to it; and cut the two veins that are in the lower lip.
Â¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	On phlebotomy Veins under the tongue after phlebotomy of the head.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	But the two veins that are under the tongue certainly require phlebotomy; because phlebotomy of the head is to remove the phlegm that is in the throat, and the disease of the throat, and the disease of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of phlebotomizing them is that the sick person sits between your hands in front of the sun; and eat his tongue, and look at the two veins on one side of the mouth, and the other vein on the other side: and the color of both should turn to black.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	So phlebotomize one and then the other; and guard, so that you don't put your hand on them when you are phlebotomizing them.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For there are arteries under them, and perhaps it happens that the flow of blood from these arteries is stopped.
Â¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Of the three veins in the cubit.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	But the three veins that are phlebotomized in the cubit, are those in which phlebotomy was customary in all people.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And phlebotomy from them is made according to two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Or by pricking with the phlebotomist on the side: or by oiling to the subtlety of the decline: or by cutting with the phlebotomist with a razor, and it is Anesiac.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is his form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Anesiac is, which is convenient to the section.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from them are species wide, and subtle according to the amplitude of the veins and their form Phlebotomy with a Myrtle sits wide, like you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is convenient to open the veins closed, full, flowing, apparent, thick, and those which contain the gross blood, turbulent.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this phlebotomist is of less amplitude, and subtler extremities.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is convenient to phlebotomy from the veins that contain the subtle citrines blood,
Â¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	Of the Phlebotomy of the Basilica.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	But the basilica which is one of the three veins phlebotomy, the iuuamentum of it is.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from the diseases which are under the throat and neck, from which follows the chest and abdomen: and it is convenient for the phlebotomist to make a cut with the phlebotome from her, so that he may not hurt, and sit over the fear from her, because there is an artery under her.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If then he should make a mistake, and adds to the cut of the phlebotomy, he will strike that artery, and will spill out the blood flow.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is convenient, so as not to phlebotomize her with a cut of the phlebotome: but sit cutting with Anesiac.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	That if not the Basilica appears by a manifest sign, then it is necessary, so as to remove her away, and turn to another, or seek some branch of it: or phlebotomize in the place of her, with a string of the brachial artery.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For this reason it is apparent, and I will dry it with the phlebotome Anesil, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	But if you wish to use the phlebotome of itself, then you should approach it before the stricture of the arm, so that you may touch the place, until you recognize the pulsation.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark the spot with caustice, then the arm as well, and dry it up with the phlebotome Anesil in a compressed section, as we have said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And let it not fall on the pulsation through space from the site of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see that, as you tighten the ligament, there is swelling in the place that you marked with caustic, then that swelling is the swelling of the artery; so remove it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	That if you see the blood rise up at phlebotomy, like a boy's urine, and it is thin blood, red in color: then you will know that it is from the blood of the artery.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then draw near, and place your finger on the spot for a long space, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	But if the blood is cut off (for it is often cut off) then tighten the arm, and let go of itself: and let there be rest from its motion: and let it lie in fear for it.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And let not the patient move for a few days, until he is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	But if the blood does not go away, and it hurts you: and is not present for you in the moment of your need; then cut the artery, if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities do quiver, and the blood is cut off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take the skin of the fist, and find it; or take half, and tighten it over the place of the stricture descending, with a ligament and dust up to another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if the blood is cut off, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	Then if not: then take care of the patient with his own recollections from the place where the blood has been cut off: and cutting off its blood is not difficult in many dispositions, because of the small wound, and the possibility of a ligament from the arm.
Â¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	On the venesection of the brown-colored blood.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	But the venesection of the brown-colored blood is a procedure that draws blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body: indeed, it is composed of the branch of the Basilica and the branch of the Cephalica, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it is fitting that the venesection should be made by one who is not afraid of phlebotomy, for under her is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore you add phlebotomy to the puncture, and find a nerve, there will be stupor in her, and the cure of her is difficult, and perhaps she will not be completely cured.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve appears often to the sense.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	But if it is hidden in some people and is subtle and does not show itself: then you should put your venesection so that the phlebotomist makes a section with Alnecil and Î±ÏÎ¿Î¼Î±ÎºÏÏÎ½Î¸ÎµÎ¯ÏÎµ from neruam with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	That if the vein is between two nerves, then find the vein in length.
Â¶ De uena Cephalica.	On the cerebral vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	But the procedure for venesection of the cerebral vein is that it draws blood from the head and renders the diseases of the eyes.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is fitting in this vein to use your own, if you wish, so that you venesection it with a phlebotomizer and oil, or with a phlebotomizer and myrrh: for this vein is salutari of all veins, because it is not subcutanea artery, nor is there a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	But it is fitting for you to go to venesection, so that you have the head only of a pig, and ask for a softer place: and it does not harm him, if it is not found with a blow first, so that it returns over it with phlebotomy sometimes.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	But perhaps he is blistered in some people when he is not phlebotomized in a blow first, but it does not harm him that blister, but that blister hurts him in a certain thing.
Â¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the usefulness of phlebotomy and precautions to be taken when performing it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of phlebotomy and the complications that may arise from it are what you should consider carefully in its correction.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	First therefore of its concerns is that you should know that phlebotomy is not performed unless for the preservation of health, and perseverance in it, and caution against the advent of illnesses.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And so that phlebotomy be made from one of three veins which are in the bed, namely the cerebral, and the femoral, and the bazilica.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And so that phlebotomy be made at the beginning of the day on a fasting stomach, in summer, and autumn, and winter after digestion, when the signs of fullness are evident.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And let phlebotomy be made on the first day, or on the third day, having elapsed three hours after the end of the day.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	But phlebotomy that is administered in illnesses does not have a determined hour: but when it provokes convenience and necessity towards it, at night, or during the day, and at any hour, and at all times.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not necessary that boys be phlebotomized until they have reached the age of fourteen.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Nor should a pregnant woman be phlebotomized until she has reached her seventh month.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	 Nor should seniors who have already passed the age of sixty be phlebotomized.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When anyone wishes to undergo phlebotomy for any reason: he should wash his intestines thoroughly before phlebotomy with castor oil, if there is much waste retained in them: so that the veins do not attract uenae, putrid effluents from the intestines, onto the main members.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Nor should a patient who is convulsed, that is, nauseous, or a drunkard until he has removed the intoxication from himself.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor an invalid with hydrophobia.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And let phlebotomy be repeated again after a fever, or a cough, or a flux of blood, or the multiplication of copulation, or labor, or exercise, or vigils, or fasting, or any that dissolves virtue from the corporeal or animal substance.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider in subtlety of humors before that, if blood is thick with food and drink, and medicines: if possible to him that.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then introduce steam, if it does not forbid itself anything: or exercise himself with some exercise, that the blood be subtilized.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And place phlebotomy in his chest, on the third day, as we have said: and be careful, so that his chest is emptied of all animal accidents on that day: such as anger, fear, and pain: and of all bodily accidents, such as labor, punishment, excess, and those like.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let him make these present things his usual use, from which custom of men by the aromatic, and fragrance, and delight, and like things by quantity of possibility.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then let the phlebotomist sit on a tray, that it be higher than the phlebotomy tray: then he shall draw out his arm, and rub himself with the phlebotomist's hand twice, or three times.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then let him tie a ligature with the thong, and twist it around: then he shall wrap it up twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let it be tight and warm, because if it is not equal, or by excess in the constriction, then it forbids the course of blood: or in mildness, then also it forbids the course of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the constriction, let the phlebotomist rub his hands together on both sides, until the veins swell, and present themselves to the sense.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the phlebotomist shall wipe the phlebotomy with a little oil, old and of his own.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then let him place his index finger of his left hand on the vein where he wants to make the phlebotomy, a little: so that the vein does not run away, and the piercing sound.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	For from the veins is it that he draws like a running string during phlebotomy: and those are full of blood: and when you place the phlebotomy on it, it is constricted by the phlebotomy, and deceives the phlebotomist, and does not open the vein: and if it opens it, then it is constricted: so that therefore it is necessary that the phlebotomist should tighten it, and be careful in all these things.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then let him deposit the phlebotomy.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If then a new vein is opened from one side, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then repeat that same vein slightly below that place or above it with speed: if the spot does not bleed.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	That if it bleeds, or grows weak, then discharge him for a day, or two days: and do not tie the ligature.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps, because the heat of the wound may attract the bleeding.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	And let him not be bathed in a bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then let him repeat the phlebotomy if he wishes it.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	That if the opening is small, or the blood runs gently: and be careful that not an excessive amount of blood comes out: then repeat the phlebotomy in the same spot according to the direction, and add a little to the procedure.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do so with speed, before that place bleeds: for a bleeder place is often found in many people during surgery.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If then you see that he has already bled, then do not repeat the phlebotomy at all: for it does not excuse with you to let anything happen.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And put something on the spot from a mixture of oil: because it softens the course of the blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And is better in this place than his own oil, and than any other oil.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And administer the same oil to all your phlebotomies when you wish to stop the course of the blood: and they make it alfarach, and saffron, when put from one of them on the spot.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	For the blood is softened and dissolved when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	That if a great apoplexy happens in the spot of phlebotomy, for many times it has happened, especially to him who is not phlebotomized except from that vein, or is an opening of a small vein, then bind and put on the spot a sponge soaked in water and salt, warmed slightly: and tie it tight for one hour: for it is dissolved.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	You should make it so that after the flow of blood from the wound itself, with its own complement, or from another new wound.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	That if it remains in the place after a few days of bruising, or redness, it does not harm that: and if there is swelling, put something on top of it of aloe, or of dissolved myrrh: or some of the juice of mint, that is, calamus or something like it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And many times indeed have there been hemorrhoids and eminences in the practice of phlebotomy at the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	So place your hand on it, then if it is soft and fragile under your pressure on it, then that eminence is evil.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Cause therefore so that you put something on it from that which I said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood will flow from it of the artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make an aplaster with it where there is stenosis, so that the place hardens.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the wound with the rest of the cure, until it heals.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is fitting that every man should give up some of his blood according to the quantity of his virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what seems to shine on the surface of the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let it not go out until it turns red: and likewise if you see it thick: then let it not go out until it thins: and likewise if it is sharp, then let the sharpness be taken away from it.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is fitting for him who is full, strong, and accustomed to the extraction of blood by a single blow, so as to increase the phlebotomy of the new one, and to be a phlebotomist on the back: but in him who is weak, be contrary to that.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is fitting that he draws out the wound with blows, and that the hole is closed tight: and better it is if it is administered in the phlebotomy of the new one, so that it is a transverse section, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of phlebotomy is safer from the flow of blood, and from the incising of nerves: and it is more praiseworthy, and healthier than phlebotomy by width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And he who is accustomed to having syncope during phlebotomy, it is necessary that he eat a little bread before phlebotomy moistened with water of gravel: or if it is cold, he should take secaniabin; and let him give himself blood in three or four vessels.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if his complexion is cold, then he should take before phlebotomy bread moistened with syrup of myrrh, or with syrup of honey flavored with spices, or with syrup flavored with odorous substances.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If syncope occurs during phlebotomy and it is the cause of a lot of blood loss, then he should drink water of meat and syrup of scent, and he should use aromatics with algarrobite, and he should open his chest while doing so: and he should use whatever we mentioned in the division on syncope from evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	But whoever wants to let his arm bleed and make up for the blood loss: it is necessary that he who does phlebotomy for extensive evacuation, and whose power is weak, should make up for the blood little by little over a certain period of time.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	But whoever wants to let his arm bleed and make up for the blood loss, and whose body is strong: then he should do it after seven or nine hours since his first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	But whoever wants to draw blood from his body towards the opposite side of which he leans: it is necessary that he should do so on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	But in the body of which there is much blood already heated and sharpened, and it causes a fever: it is necessary that he should get out of it blood in one vessel, and extract from it a great quantity; and increase the opening until syncope occurs: after that you have kept all the conditions of phlebotomy: and let your hand rest on his pulse during the course of the blood, so that syncope does not occur at the place.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	For many times this has happened when the phlebotomizer is careless, and he falls by neglect.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not right that you should tie the arm when you wish to cut, and cut the blood according to the second way, when the orifice of the vein has already been closed, and let the exit of the blood be difficult, so that it rushes over itself with a sudden movement, and let it curve and extend quickly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For this is bad to tie tightly, let go of it until the blood is bled by the second way.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or move it with sharpness of phlebotomy this that is coagulated from blood at the orifice of the vein, and put over it something dissolved in water of salt.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And put over it some of the alkaloids of the arnica, or of the sage, and put the compress on it gently until the blood exits.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	But if the vein is already torn, then let go of it, and do not tie it, until it has healed.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	That if necessity compels to bleed by the second way, and there is no excuse, then either phlebotomize the person above that place, or in the arm of another in a different vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	But the vein of the arm is phlebotomized at the place of the fuscus and basilica, when they are not found, and are hidden, since it is composed of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of the phlebotomy of it is, that it should put the hand of the sick in hot water, until it turns red, and the vein appears clearly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then tie over it with a little tight binding on the middle.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then bleed by the second way little by little, not wide, and not along its length: and let the opening be wide, and let your bleeding be over the vein a little.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	That if the exit of the blood is prevented, then again put the hand in hot water, and let the blood run into the water, until you have satisfied your need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	But if you are in the days of summer, then you are excused from again putting the hand in hot water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	For certainly the course of blood is put into warm water at the time of the winter.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And phlebotomy of this vein is salutary for all veins, because there is no pulsation of blood under it, and there are no nerves.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	On the right hand, phlebotomy is salutary for those with liver sickness.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of phlebotomy is such that you squeeze the hand with a ligature, or your own hand, after you have put it into warm water, until the blood stirs and shows by touch to be very cold.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then phlebotomize it by passing through.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut it entirely, it will not hurt him at all.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And keep your hand away from the phlebotomy after.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Because under it are naked nerves of the fingers stripped of their flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then repeat the hand to warm water, and let the blood flow into it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not heat the hand in warm water, the blood will clot in the incision of the vein, and the course will be stopped.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	But when you extract a quantity of blood as needed, then put oil and salt on the vein so that it does not consolidate quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And likewise it is necessary to do the same with all branches that are tight.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The instruction for the phlebotomy of the left hand is this: because it is salutary for heart sickness; and likewise do the same for the phlebotomy of it as you did in the second place equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The instruction for the phlebotomy of the saphenous vein is this: for diseases that are in the lower part of the body, such as those of the kidneys, and retention of the monthly flow, and sickness of the kidneys and bladder, and old sores of the legs and feet, and other similar ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is such that he puts his sick foot into warm water; and let him make friction on it until the blood comes out; and bind above the ligature with a thong.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And this place is even on the calcaneus, appearing opposite to the thumb; and many branches emerge from it in front of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Therefore let her bleed from a larger branch of her, or at the calcaneus in their gathering; for it is better and more salutary.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If she should bleed from before the foot, then be careful of the nerves which are under her on the surface of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And put your phlebotomy where you want to phlebotomize her from behind, as if you wished to pierce her; and let the phlebotomy be done.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If however the blood flow is forbidden, then turn her other foot to warm water; and let not the blood run into her until it has drained off.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	If however there is an error in the phlebotomizing of the first vein, then let it remain with the phlebotomy up to the same degree, for the place is salutary; and do not wait for it from the malice, when you cauterize the nerves, as we said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And likewise with the saphenous vein of the other foot equally.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	But the location of the sciatic veins, as we said, is on the calcaneus from the lateral side.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the incision for her phlebotomy is, to the pain of the ankle, when it is due to the warm blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of her phlebotomy is, that it should enter into an infirm bath, and cause a tingling; and tightly tie her foot from the lateral ankle up to the calcaneus with a long and slender thread: for it does not appear otherwise than because of this.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When however it appears, then phlebotomize her according to whatever talent you have, or at the location; and it is better, or as if you should pierce her with an incision, or cut her off by a section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For the place of her is salutary, and she herself is hidden from many people greatly.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If however you do not feel her at all: then phlebotomize some of her branch, and that which appears on the back of the foot, and opposite to the ear; and cauterize the nerves, and let blood run in quantity as much as you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then cut the strip tightly, and put it on the place where the blood has been let, and tighten the place.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	For this quickly heals.
Â¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	(Concerning Wind-sucking and its quality of use.)
Caput XCVIII.	CHAPTER LVIII. ON WIND-SUCKING AND ITS QUALITY OF
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Wind-sucking takes place from horns, and from air, and from moisture.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And Wind-sucking takes place in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	(With scarification and the extraction of blood) one is Wind-sucking with scarification, and extraction of blood; and another is Wind-sucking without
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	(And this Wind-sucking, which is without scarification), takes place in two ways: one is
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or on the other hand it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And those Wind-suckings which are performed with scarification and extraction of blood, are four places in the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	Of these four places in the body are: one is Wind-sucking of the Alnocrati, and it is at last of the head: and Alkehel, and it is in the middle of the neck: and uenosas Alhagdahim, and there are two laminae of the neck from both sides simultaneously: and uentosas of the mind, and it is under the mandible in the lower mouth: and uentosas of two spatulas: and uentosas of the tail; and uentosas of two flames, and they are in the middle of the two arms: and uentosas of the two chaps: and uentosas of the two shoulders.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	(And Wind-sucking does not extract blood from you from small scattered veins in the flesh, and for this reason its power does not fall out of them, as is the case with phlebotomy.)
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Nor does it need to be administered Wind-sucking either with fire or without fire in any sickness which happens from fullness, until the whole body has been emptied.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If need calls for Wind-sucking because of sickness, or because of custom, let it be administered at the beginning, end, and middle of the month, and at any time.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	For it is because he is a man who, when blood multiplies within him, does not become ill from its extraction by vomiting, but remains in his head giddiness and dizziness.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And of them is he who finds swelling and redness on his face, on his head, and on his neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And of them is he who finds itching on his face, on his forehead, darkness, and dullness in his eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And of them is he who scratches the place of his venesection.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And of them is he whose laughter multiplies.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And of them is he who finds the taste of blood in his mouth, or spits it out with his tongue, and vomits up blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And of them is he whose sleep multiplies.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And of them is he who sees in his sleep blood and redness, and slain men, and plagues, and things like those.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When then do we perform venesection if we see anything of them, and especially if it is in the third month from the beginning of the month: let us then perform it after two or three hours have passed since the middle of the day.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	But the venesection of the nape is: for it turns to giddiness in the head, and because it flows out into the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	But it should be done after emptying the whole body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this venesection is at a place phlebotomy of the head.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it should not be used as a person with a cold complexional appearance, or one who is hoarse.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it inflicts great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And because of that, it should not be used as a person who has old age, and in whose head there are diseases of cold.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	But whoever is accustomed to it, he gets over it by oblivion.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And because of that, you should order the venesection, so that he lays his hand with a gentle press down below, fearing the generation of oblivion.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Ventosatio or Alkehel is the place of the Phlebothymia of Fuscae and of the Basilica; for that reason it provides relief from asma, constriction of the windpipe, the instrument's fissures, cough, and congestion.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it should be that Ventosa Alkehel is pushed further back, because if it is placed lower, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	But Ventosa Alkehel, it brings relief to the pains of accidents in the head, and to the eyes, and to the headaches, and to the perforations, and to the pain in the roots of the teeth; and it is the place of phlebotomy of the Basilica.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And it should be that you prevent the Ventosator from touching his hand with the scarification, so that he does not hit an artery and cause a flow of blood.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	But Ventosa under the chin, brings alcohol into the mouth, and corruption of the gums, and similar ailments that are in the mouth: and it is the place of phlebotomy of Alieherich, which are in the two lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	But Ventosa spatulas, brings relief to alchafacham, which is made from a vibration and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	But Ventosa of the inner parts, brings relief to the phlebotomy of the three veins, Basilicae, and Fuscae, and Cephalicae: because it itself attracts blood from all those tiny veins that are in the flesh: and these tiny veins attract the blood from other larger veins until it reaches the attraction of the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And it should be that you prevent the Ventosator from going too deeply in the scarification, because the place is deprived of flesh, and under it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	But Ventosa that is applied on Alchazaus, brings hemorrhoids of the Anus, and ulcers of the lower parts.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And it should be that you prevent the Ventosator from making the Ventosa too small, and that it is made of iron: because the place does not endure strong suction, and perhaps the fine Ventosas break: and it is scarified with a large scarification.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	The veins of the legs diminish and are evident because they draw blood from all over the body, and increase old pains in the kidneys, uteruses, and urinary bladder; induce menstruation, and produce bothorrhea and emesis; and stand at the site of phlebotomy of the two saphenous veins, and alhorcobeni.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	However, they weaken the body greatly, and cause fainting in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And the alhorcobeni of the two leg veins is a close connection to the alhorcobeni of the two saphenous veins.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of the leg vein is that you place the venose in the first place empty, and suck with a moderate temper: and do not prolong the position of the veins, but put them quickly, and move them quickly so that the humors go to the site of adventitious equally: and do not cease to repeat this and continue, until you see the site has already turned red and swollen, and appears to be red blood: then therefore cut, and repeat sucking slowly.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider in the disposition of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For he who is among men of tender flesh and rare pores, should cut himself once, not more: so that the site does not ulcerate.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And prescribe to the venous cutter, so that he amplifies the cutting, and digs a little: and moderates sucking in convenience, and speed, and smooth movement.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	That if there is thickness in the blood, then you should cut himself twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In a vessel, however, the first opening is a path of subtilization of blood, and its liquification: and in the second, indeed, the perscrutation of exquisite extraction of thick blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	But if the blood is very foul, then let there be a third cutting: so that it leads to the last.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And to the last, when we wish to extract blood slowly, or little by little, a single cutting is sufficient for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	If we wish to extract a lot of blood, we make many incisions.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure, that the blood is thick: then it is necessary, so that the incision is deep: and the term equal in the incision, is the depth of the skin.
Â¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What is that which needs to be administered from oils during the placement of the ventosas, and what causes the veno-sandus.
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	In that indeed whose skin is thick, hard, dark, and the pores of which are tight, it is necessary that the places of the ventosas are anointed with open, soothing, and resolved oils: if it is in the time of summer, as is the oil of a number of things, or oil of caraway, or oil of almonds, or seed-oil.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in the time of winter, then oil of narcissus, or oil of lilies, or oil of chamomile, or oil of mustard: and to these similar ones.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	But if there is too much coldness, then oil of bitter-fennel, or oil of benzoe, or oil of albus, or oil of annatto: and to these similar ones.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	But if the veno-sandus is of large pores, of tender flesh: then it is necessary that there be a prohibition from oil, and that these anoint the places of the ventosas after the veno-sandus with rose-water, or cold water, or water of the marigolds, or seed-cress-water: and to these similar ones.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	That one whom the blood is of much moisture, he washes the ventosas with vinegar, or with water of myrtle, and of sumach: and to these similar ones.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	Whom the excessives are thick, he washes his ventosas with old wine, or water of samphire, or decoction of anetium, or of chamomile: and to these similar ones.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it is necessary that the veno-sandus be caused in a bath, or in a dressing-room of the bath: and it is necessary that be administered after going out from the bath for an hour, or for two hours.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And it is not appropriate for anyone to sleep after wound care.
Â¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	What is the need for someone to be fed or bled before wound care.
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	And after that, it is necessary to consider the first things: if the person is cholericky and there is an acuteness and inflammation in his blood then it is necessary for him to take cooling things like granulated mulberry: also dandelion with vinegar and lettuce and secanabium and juice.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	And place on his food porridge and meat that is sour, and cooked food with acorn: and similar things.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	And if his complexio is cold then it is necessary for him to take syrup of honey or almond or alsecaniabin made from seeds in wine: and he should take medium-strong wine that is between new and old: and let him be directed to eat a little food.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	And place on his food porridge and hay: and pigeons, that is, many birds: and let him eat pigeon pellets.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And it is necessary for the wine of wound care and phlebotomy to be stronger than food: and it is necessary for it to be given in a drink to some people in hours of tyrrhenic alfaroch or medicine of musk, that is muscata, or alesselithe before wound care: and before phlebotomy or after: so as to strengthen the main muscles and refine the blood.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	And it is not appropriate for them to drink it in hot wine.
Â¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	Of wound care without scarring.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	But wound care that is without scarring are those that are placed on the liver, and the spleen, and the podanum, and over the windpipe, and the navel, and places of the reins, and the pixied anus: because these members do not undergo scarring on themselves.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	And it is not sought for them except for an attactio from one member of blood to a member: such as we place Wound care on the breasts in a fever of blood flow.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	And we use them so that we can heal a cold, irritated member of the body, in the same way as we put wind on the belly and navel.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	For it itself tightens up the member, and warms it, and takes away the pain because it has healed that cold irritation.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	Also, it is placed on the hips when there is an accumulation of fluid or a stone.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	For its own power of attraction may perhaps open up an accumulation or remove a stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	And it is the same when placed on the liver and the spleen to relieve any irritation in them. For in both cases, if there is an accumulation of wind, it opens it up.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	And these Wind-relievers are applied with a slight cut only.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	And sometimes they are applied with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	And sometimes they are applied, filled with warm water, in cases of pleural pain; and that is to say, so that it becomes full of the Wind-reliever, and great in size, with just warm water alone, or with water in which have been boiled the herbs that are suitable.
Â¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	The form of the application of the Wind-relievers with fire:
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	Let the width of its opening be that of two fingers put together, according to the form we have given; and let the quantity of it in the depth be half the length of a palm: and let it be placed on one side of the member at the point which is about halfway along it, a small hole, according to the quantity which is put into it: let it be made of brass, or yellow metal, broad-edged, smooth, equal, sharp, or triangular: so that it does not hurt the member at the point where it is placed on top of it: and let there be a cross-bar of brass, or iron, where the candle is placed with fire.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	And this great Wind-reliever can also be made, larger than we have described, and a slightly smaller one, according to the diseases and age of the person who uses it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	For the Wind-relievers are different for boys, and those which weaken are different from those which relieve men, and from those which are suitable for large bodies.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.	The quality of this placement of the wound with fire on the limb is that, as you light the linseed oil with fire from linen that is out of center, or a candle made of pitch: and place it in the middle of the hip bone across which is in the middle of the wound: so that the fire is set around the lower part of the wound, so that the body does not burn.
Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.	Then place on the limb and the finger is placed on the hole that I said, as long as we hold the wound open: while we are holding it open, let us remove the finger, and steam will come out of that hole and immediately dissolve the wound.
Deinde igni licinium secundum modum suum, et itera eam, si indiges illa.	Then with oil fire according to its way, and repeat it if you are not used to it.
In Ventosa autem quae administratur in aegritudine pleuresis cum aqua, non est uirga transuersa, neque foramen: et non administratur, nisi quia impletur aqua, et ponitur super membrum tantum.	But in the wound that is administered with water in pleurisy disease, there is no transverse hip bone or hole: and it is not administered unless it is filled with water, and placed only on the limb.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	And this wound is the more large one, because it takes a lot of water, it is better.
Â¶ De suspensione Sanguisugarum.	The suspension of blood sugar.
Caput XCIX.	Head 99.
Sanguisugae non administrantur in pluribus, nisi in quibus membris non est possibilis positio uentosarum, propter paruitatem eorum, sicut labium, et gingiua, et eis similia.	Blood sugar is not administered in many places unless the limb cannot be placed on a wound due to its smallness, such as a lip, and gums, and similar ones.
Aut in membro denudato a carne, sicut digitus, et nasus, et eis similia.	Or in a naked member from meat, such as a finger, and nose, and similar things.
Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.	And the quality of using them is that you come from blood sugar that is in sweet waters, clean from corruption.
Deinde dimittantur die et nocte in aqua dulci, donec famelicae sint, et non remaneat in uentre earum aliquid.	Then they are left off during the day and night in sweet water, until they become hungry, and nothing remains in their stomachs.
Deinde euacuetur corpus in primis cum phlebotomia, et cum uentosis.	Then the body is emptied out with phlebotomy, and with wound opening.
Deinde absterge membrum infirmi, donec rubeat.	Then the limb is washed, until it turns red.
Postea ponantur super ipsum.	Then they are placed on top of it.
Cum ergo implentur, et cadunt, et est possibilis suctio loci cum uentosa, tunc est magis ultimum in iuuamento: et si non, tunc ablue locum cum aceto.	When therefore they are filled and fall, and it is possible to suck the place with a flowing [blood], then it is more appropriate to tie up: and if not, then suck the place with vinegar.
Deinde cum aqua multa, et fricetur, et exprimatur.	Then, when there is much water, and it is frothed and pressed out.
Quod si prolongatur cursus sanguinis post casum Sanguisugarum, et est illud resudando: tunc infunde pannum lini in aqua frigida, et pone ipsum desuper, donec abscindatur resudatio.	If the course of blood continues after the loss of blood from the wound and there is a residue: then put a cloth made of linen into cold water, and let it rest on top until the residue has dried up.
Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	If the blood multiplies, then sprinkle powder on top of the wound, crushed eggshell, or similar things from astringent: until the blood has dried up.
Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	Or place on top of the place half of crushed herbs that are used to stop bleeding: and let them be left until the herbs have stuck to the place, because the blood has dried up.
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	And it is necessary if the necessity arises to repeat the application of bloodletting, when it is possible, to change them.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	If however bloodletting by suspension is prohibited, then the place is cleaned with recently flowing blood.
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	Or tie it up now on the places until something of the blood goes out.
