And let him lie on his back: and his head should be placed between two cloths so that he does not move to the right or left: and he should not be forced to chew anything: but soft food should be given to him to eat, until such time as his jaw no longer hurts, and it is closed: then he can eat what he wants, and administer it easily.
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	He should not work on the operation of his mouth during digestion and drinking, and whistling, until such time as the jaw is closed, and healed.
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	That if the reduction of both jaws is difficult when they are dislocated at some time, and do not return to their places: then often occur there fevers, and frequent farts: and perhaps a swollen belly, and perhaps pure cholera.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	For this reason you see that loss; for if you don't know, it is a loss, and he often dies who gets this in ten days.
Â¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	The Reduction of the Dislocation of the Furcula and Extremity of the Humerus
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26: The Head
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	The furcula does not dislocate from its inner side, because it continues with the chest.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	And it dislocates sometimes towards the outside; and that is felt by touch.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	And its restoration is such that he lies on his back and extends his arms.
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	Then gird your hand with the garter; for it will return by itself.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	Then place a pad on it, and feathers, and tighten it.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	The extremities, however, which follow the bed and continue with him, rarely dislocate.
Quod si dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	If it dislocates on one day: then let it be reduced and made equal as we have said, and let you be prepared.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	Then place a pad on it, and feathers, and tighten it.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	And tell the sick person to adhere to rest and quietness until he is healed.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	And with this same cure the extremity of the humerus is reduced when it separates from its place as well.
Â¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	The Reduction of the Dislocation of the Humerus
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27: The Head
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	You should know that the humerus does not dislocate unless by three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	The first is that it dislocates towards the upper arm towards the lower side.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	The second is that it dislocates towards the chest.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	And perhaps it dislocates towards the upper part of the humerus, and that is rare.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	And it does not dislocate from behind, because of the scapula.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	And it does not dislocate from the front, because of the nerves.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	It dislocates and moves towards the lower side towards the titillus; mainly in those who have little flesh there.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	For he who enters them quickly exits and quickly enters.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	But in those whose flesh is abundant, the opposite holds, that is, because he exits with difficulty and enters with difficulty.
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	And perhaps it happens to some men that they are struck or fall and dislocated their shoulder. They say that because it is already dislocated.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	Therefore, let you experience that thing until you are certain about its status, and then proceed to treat it.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	And be known the dislocation when it is towards the lower side of the joint: and distinguish between a dislocated shoulder and a healthy one.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	For you will find a great difference between them: and in the head of the arm there is an ache, and under the touch almost as if it were itself; and cannot bring the hand to its ear, nor move it in all movements.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	And likewise, if it is dislocated towards the chest or upward: then there is a clear feeling of touch, and it does not hide itself away.
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	And of this dislocation, its reduction is easy when it is young or a weak boy.
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	And its reduction is, so that you lift your hand up toward the sky.
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	Then put your fingers under its touch and join them together with strength upward to their place: and lift your hand up and extend it downward.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	Then put it down again, for himself he returns quickly.
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	But if it does not return by that which we have said, and there are many days from the time of dislocation: then let the infirm person bathe in hot water, and apply an ointment that softens and soothes, such as if they were cooked the roots of aloe, and foenugraecum, and melilotum in water, and it is applied.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	Then the infirm person shall lie down on his back: and a ball and wool be placed under its touch, which is equal between the soft and the tight.
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	Then let the physician put his calcaneum on the sphere, and he shall raise the head of the humerus with force, and draw the hand of the nurse downward.
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	And another shall hold the head of the nurse so that she does not move downward: for he will immediately return to his stand.
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	And if you wish, reduce him according to this manner: and it is so, that you may make the man who is longer ill present, and stand at his side, and introduce his humerus under the hand of the nurse: and lift up her hand to the upper part, until he be suspended in the air.
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	And another shall hold the hand of the nurse downward toward the thigh of the patient.
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	If the man is light: then it shall be necessary that something else should hold him up with it, so that he does not fall down: for he will immediately return to his dislocation.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	And he shall be reduced also according to another manner: and it is so, that he is placed on the ground a long wooden piece, whose head is round in figure: as the handle of a mortar: which neither is too coarse nor too fine.
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	Then let it be placed under the patient after that they are placed on the head of the wood, and the cloth made of soft fabric; and let the patient stand according to the length of the wood.
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then shall his hand be extended downward from the other part, and shall his body be extended from one side with force: for the joint returns to its place with velocity.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	That if his reduction is difficult by all the things which we have said, then use this cure: and it is so, that you take a piece of wood whose length is two times that of the arm, and whose breadth is four times that of the fingers, and whose thickness is two times that of the fingers: and whose head is round, that it may ease the entrance into his depth according to this form.
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	Then let them bind on the round head with soft cloth so that they do not wound the wood on the patient.
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	Then place the nurse under the tickle, so that the hand is extended, or the arm over the wood until it reaches the lower part: and tie the wood on the support and the arm and the end of the hand.
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	Then place the arm over the steps across the width, and extend the hand towards the lower part, and dismiss the remaining body suspended from the other side.
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	For the wound to be sewed immediately.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	When this entry is therefore finished in whatever way possible: then you should place a ball of equal size made from wool under the tickle.
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	Then place the prepared plaster made from ground stone with incense and albite on the whole shoulder as it turns away upwards.
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	Then tighten the knot under the tickle as it goes down: and wrap the ligament around the plaster upwards: and attach her hand to her neck, and dismiss it, and do not move her hand for seven days.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	And you should place a meager diet for the member until it is healed: for it is faster to heal with it.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	Then place a broader one after seven or five days, and exercise it with movement.
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	But if it remains firm and does not weaken, then it is healed now.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	But if the wound dislocates many times, because of the moisture that occurs with it, or for any other reason: then you should administer a cauterization with three holes, as was mentioned in the chapter on cauterization.
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	If all of this is done, and the ligament is loosened after seven days, and the wound does not close with the plaster and the knot many times, and does not firm up, and falls down, and cannot raise it upwards: then you should know that the nerves which are in the shoulder have been cut or stretched or weakened: and you should know that the wound never closes in its place.
Dislocationis autem quae fit uersus pectus et mammillam, aut ad posteriora reductio, fit cum impulsione et extensione cum manibus: donec redeat, et administretur in ea reliqua strictura et cura, donec sanetur.	But the dislocation which happens towards the chest and the nipple, or to the rear, is caused by a push and an extension with the hands: until it stops, and administer a remaining knot and care, until it heals.
Quod si accidat post sanationem grauitas in membro, et tarditas in motu eius, tunc utatur infirmus balneo multotiens, donec leniatur illa grauitas, et redeat ad naturam eius primam.	If it should happen after recovery of the strength of a member, and delay in its movement, then let the sick person use the bath often, until that strength is relieved, and return him to his natural state first.
Â¶ De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.	On the Treatment of Dislocation of the Elbow.
Caput XXVIII.	HEAD XXVIII.
Scias, quod iunctura Cubiti dislocatur cum difficultate, et similiter redit cum difficultate etiam: et ipsa quidem dislocatur ad omnes partes, et praecipue ad anteriorem, aut ad posteriorem.	Know that the elbow joint dislocates with difficulty, and likewise returns with difficulty to all parts, especially to the front or back.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	And its dislocation is not hidden from you: for it falls under your sight and under your touch, according to whatever figure it dislocates.
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	And when you join together a dislocated elbow that has recovered its strength, it becomes manifest to you.
Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	For the dislocation is twisted, and it cannot bend the arm, nor can it touch the shoulder with it.
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And you should reduce the dislocation at once, before it experiences a hot swelling.
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	For if it happens to that elbow joint that a hot swelling occurs, it is difficult to reduce it; and it may be that it does not heal at all, especially when it is dislocated towards the back.
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	This is worse in every respect to dislocation, and more painful to the arm: and often dies with it.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And when its restoration is from among those that can be reduced, it extends its hand with both hands: and the arm is spread out, and the fingers of the hand are placed above the elbow joint and under it, and he pushes back the dislocation with his thumbs of his hands simultaneously, or with the base of his palm, until he returns to his place.
Aut uero dislocatio est ad anteriora: tunc redit ita, ut duplicet manum cum manu sua, donec percutiat cum radice palmae suae cubitum qui est dislocatus.	Or, on the other hand, the dislocation is towards the front: then he returns so that he doubles his hand with his own hand, until he strikes against the base of his palm the elbow joint that has been dislocated.
Quod si non obedit dislocatio ad reductionem, tunc administra extensionem uehementem, fortem ualde: et est, ut extendant brachium duo ministri: et teneant ipsum duo ministri etiam, ut non remoueatur apud extensionem.	If the dislocation does not submit to reduction, then administer a sharp extension, a strong rub: and it is as if two ministers extend the arm: and they hold him also, so that he does not move during the extension.
Deinde reuoluatur brachium ad omnem partem postquam inuoluitur super manum eius pannus duplicatus longus, aut ligamentum latum.	Then the arm is to be rotated back to its full extent after it has been enveloped with a doubled-over cloth or wide bandage on his hand.
Et quando tangit medicus manu sua iuncturam, inungat ipsam cum oleo: ut sit illud ex eis quae adiuuant in lubricitate iuncturae cum facilitate.	And when the doctor touches with his own hand the joint, he should dip it in oil: so that it may be from those which help in the lubrication of the joint by ease.
Deinde impellat iuncturam impulsione uehementi, donec redeat.	Then he should push the joint with a sharp push, until it is released.
Et post reductionem eius oportet, ut ponatur super ipsam emplastrum, in quo sit stipticitas, et exiccatio cum albugine oui: et stringatur strictura decenti.	And after the reduction of it, it should be placed on it a plaster, in which sits the clotting, and drying with alum: and let it be tightened by tightening while healing.
Et suspendatur brachium a collo infirmi: et dimitte diebus aliquot.	And hang the arm from the neck of the nurse: and let it be left for several days.
Deinde soluatur.	Then unfasten.
Si ergo firmatur iunctura in loco suo, tunc solue ligamentum ab ea, et dimitte ipsam.	If then the joint remains fixed in its place, then loosen the bandage from it, and let it be left.
Et si uides iuncturam non bene stringi, tunc itera emplastrum, et ligamentum, et dimitte ipsam diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	And if you see that the joint is not tightly tightened, then repeat the plaster, and the bandage, and let it be left for several days, until it is tightened.
Deinde solue ipsam.	Then unfasten it.
Si autem accidit ei grauitas post reductionem iuncturae, et dispositio sit in motu: tunc administra humectationem in balneatione, et fricationem subtilem, et compressionem, donec liniatur, aut pone super iuncturam iliati, id est, natem arietis pinguem.	If however it has happened to him that he is light after the reduction of the joint, and the disposition is in movement: then administer moistening in bathing, and subtle rubbing, and compression, until it is healed, or put on top of the joint an ileum, that is, a piece of chamois leather.
Deinde ligetur, et dimitte ipsam super eam die et nocte.	Then tighten it, and let it be left on it day and night.
Deinde aufer eam, et intromitte ipsum in balneum.	Then take it off, and let him enter the bath.
Cum ergo sudat, tunc frica iuncturam fricatione temperata.	When however he sweats, then rub the joint with moderate rubbing.
Deinde itera super ipsam aleliati uice una, et secunda, et tertia cum introitu balnei, donec leniatur.	Then repeat on top of him a piece of chamois leather once, and twice, and third time at the entrance to the bath, until it is relaxed.
Et si uis, pone super ipsam stercus uaccinum, humidum, calefactum cum butyro, et stringe super ipsum.	And if you want, put on top of him a heap of fine mud, moist, heated with butter, and tighten over him.
Fac illud aliquotiens.	Let it be done several times.
Ipsa namque lenitur, et redit ad dispositionem suam.	It is healed, and returns to its own disposition.
Â¶ De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.	De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.
Caput XXIX.	On the treatment of dislocations by Al-Mahassari
Mahassem manus multotiens dislocatur, id est, iunctura quae est inter brachium et manum.	If the wrist is dislocated, that is, the joint between the arm and the hand is disconnected, then...
Et reductio dislocationis eius est facilis.	And reducing the dislocation of it is easy.
Econtrario reliquarum iuncturarum.	Contrary to the remaining joints.
Verumtamen oportet, ut uelocitas sit in reductione dislocationis eius in hora in qua dislocatur, antequam apostemetur locus: aut accidat in eo apostema calidum.	However, it is necessary that the speed be in the reduction of the dislocation at the time when it is dislocated, before the measurement is taken: or happens in that measure warmth.
Et reductio dislocationis in eo est, ut ponas Mahassem manus infirmae super tabulam, et extendat minister manum eius: et ponat medicus palmam suam super eminentiam iuncturae, et impellat eam, donec redeat.	And reducing the dislocation is, so that you put Al-Mahassari's weak hand on a table, and extends his assistant hand: and puts the doctor's palm on the eminence of the joint, and pushes it until it returns.
Verumtamen oportet, ut consyderetur, si palma iam recessit ad uentrem manus: tunc ponat infirmus dorsum manus suae super tabulam apud extensionem et reductionem: et si dislocatio est procedens ad dorsum manus, tunc sit positio manus eius intrinsece super tabulam, id est, interior pars manus eius super tabulam ponatur, ut cadat manus medici super ipsam eminentiam iuncturae.	However, it is necessary that you consider whether the palm has already reached the stomach of the hand: then put the weak back of the hand on a table with extension and reduction: and if the dislocation is going to the back of the hand, then the position of the hand should be inside the table, that is, the interior part of the hand should be placed on the table, so that the doctor's palm rests on it.
Si ergo redit statim, bonum est: et si non, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro sedante apostema: et dimitte ipsum, neque iteres illud.	If then he returns immediately, it is good: and if not, then bind it with a plaster while the Apostema is resting: and let go of it, and do not return to it.
Nam si non tolerat, neque potes super reductionem eius, postquam praetereunt ei dies, uerumtamen iunctura remanet secundum tortuositatem suam: et non nocet infirmo aliquid, nisi quod mollificatur manus, et non potest stringere aliquid: tunc scias, quod nerui sunt abscissi, aut attriti.	For if it does not bear, and you cannot reduce it, after a few days, the joint remains according to its torsion: and does not hurt the weak man, unless the hand is softened, and he cannot grasp anything: then know that the nerves have been cut off, or rubbed.
Non est ergo ingenium in ea, nisi ut stringatur cum cauterio prope casum eius.	So there is no skill in it, except that it is bound with a bandage close to its danger.
Et fortasse non confert illud aliquid.	And perhaps it doesn't matter.
Cum ergo non redit Almahassem, tunc pone super ipsum emplastrum, quod narrauimus.	But since Al-Mahassari does not return, then put the plaster on him, which we have described.
Deinde stringatur, et dimittatur quinque diebus: postea soluatur et dimittatur, et exercitetur manus.	He should then be strung up and left for five days; afterwards he should be unstrung and left, and his hands exercised.
Si autem priuatur motus eius, et accidat in ea aliquid grauitatis: tunc leni eam cum aqua calefacta, et fricatione aliquotiens, donec leniatur.	But if he is deprived of movement and something heavy happens to him: then make him soft with warm water and sometimes rubbing, until he becomes soft.
Â¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	The cure for dislocation of the fingers.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30 on the head.
Quando dislocatur ex eis Digitus ad omnem partem, uel ex eis Digitus ad dorsum palmae, aut uentrem eius: tunc extende Digitum, et impelle dislocationem pollicibus tuis, donec redeat.	When a finger is dislocated completely, or one of the fingers is dislocated towards the back of the hand, or the thumb is inside it: then extend the finger and push with your thumbs until it returns to its place.
Deinde sustenta caput Digiti, et suspende ipsum uersus partem ad quam dislocatur, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	Then support the head of the finger and hang it on the side where it is dislocated for two days.
Deinde suspende eum, et extende ipsum, donec aequetur rectus in illo die suo.	Then hang him up and extend him, until he becomes straight again on his own day.
Cum ergo fuerit nox, liga ipsum secundum narrationem ipsam: et non cesses soluere ipsum in die: et exerce eum cum motu: et liga ipsum in nocte.	When it is night, bind him according to the above narrative: and do not stop from unbinding him on that day: and exercise him with movement: and bind him at night.
Fac illud diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	Make those days a few, until he is strangled.
Et similiter fac cum eo, si dislocatur ad uentrem manus: et liga eum ad partem ipsam, et fac cum eo operationem tuam primam, donec sanetur.	And also do the same with him if he is dislocated towards the palm of the hand: and bind him on that side, and perform your operation on him, until he heals.
Et similiter fac cum eo quando dislocatur ad reliquas partes.	And also do the same with him when he is dislocated in other parts.
Â¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	The cure for dislocation of the spine of the back.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31 on the head.
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	When something like this happens to someone: there is no cure for it, because death approaches the sick.
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	And a sign of this is that the sick person leaves the bed of their own will, and cannot hold on to it: and often some limb of theirs weakens, or two limbs, or two arms, or one arm: or one of the spines leaves its place. Or one of the spines is dislocated from one of its places.
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	Many times, therefore, they are removed, as many times is the removal made towards the four sides.
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	Those which are moved towards the rear, then, are called Girdles.
Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	The cure, however, is this, that you should consider then, if Girdles occur from infancy: then there is no cure at all from it, nor is there any healing at all from it.
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.	But in that which occurs from accident, or blow, or similar things, the ancient doctors have long ago spoken of the methods of cure.
Cuius plurimum non redit cum proficuo.	Whose much does not return with profit.
Ego uero iam abbreuiaui ex illo, cuius parum excusat a multo eius ex propinquitate mea ad intentionem: et expositione mea qua exposui illud, et formaui instrumentum eius diuerso modo ab eo quo ostenderunt illud, et exposuerunt ipsum.	I have, however, abbreviated from that, of which little excuses its much nearness to me with regard to my intention: and my exposition of it, which I exposed, and formed a different instrument from him from which they showed it, and exhibited itself.
Dico ergo, quod in gibbositate quae accidit ab anteriori parte, non est ingenium, neque sanatio ex ea.	I say, then, that in the girdle which occurs from the front part, there is no art nor healing from it.
Et similiter in illa quae fit ad duo latera etiam.	And similarly in that which occurs on both sides also.
Et non curatur ex eis, nisi illa quae accidit in dorso proprie, cum eo quod ego narro: et est, ut extendatur infirmus super faciem suam super podium aequale prope parietem: et expandatur sub eo stramentum humidum, ut non laedatur pectus eius.	And they are not cured from them, unless that which occurs in the back own, with what I am telling you: and it is, so that he extends himself on his face on a level platform near the wall: and he expands himself under him a damp cloth, so that his chest is not injured.
Deinde ponatur lignum rectum fixum in fouea in terra, in extremitate podii, circiter caput eius: et lignum aliud circiter pedes eius in extremitate altera podii: et minister teneat lignum, et sit non firmatum in fouea.	Then a straight piece of wood is placed in the mud on the ground at the end of his foot, about his head: and another piece of wood around his feet at the other end of the other foot: and the servant holds the wood, and sits it not fixed in the mud.
Et minister alter teneat alterum.	And the other servant hold another.
Deinde inuolue super caput infirmi, et sub titillicis eius ligamentum lene, firmum: et extende extremitatem ligamenti ad lignum quod est apud caput eius: et liga ipsum in eo.	Then he turns himself about on his head, and under his chin with a soft ligature firmly: and extends the end of the ligament to the wood which is by his head: and ties it on him.
Deinde stringe ligamentum aliud supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et apud cauillas eius.	Then he tightens another ligature above his shoulders, and above his knees, and at his heels.
Deinde aggrega ligamenta omnia, et liga ea in ligno altero quod est apud pedes eius.	Then secure all the ligaments, and tie them to another piece of wood which is at his feet.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem ligni ligamentum, et non remoueantur duo ligna ex locis suis in quibus sunt fixa: uerumtamen non sint firmata, sicut diximus.	Then all the attendants should stretch out to the timber of the ligaments, and not remove the two timbers from their places where they are fixed: verily, however, they are not fixed, as we have said.
Et medicus ponat palmas suas super Spondilem cum fortitudine, donec redeat: aut ponat super eam tabulam.	And the doctor should place his palms on the spine with strength until he has recovered: or he should place it on the panel.
Deinde annectat super tabulam pedes suos, donec redeat.	Then he attaches his feet to the panel until he has recovered.
Si autem non redit per hanc curationem, tunc accipe tabulam cuius longitudo sit circiter tria brachia.	But if he does not recover with this treatment, then take a panel whose length is about three arm-lengths.
Et caua in pariete de quo diximus quod est prope infirmum, locum in quem ingrediatur extremitas tabulae.	And fasten one end of the panel to the wall that we have mentioned, which is near the sick man, at the end into which he should enter.
Deinde pone medium tabulae super Spondilem.	Then place the middle of the panel on the spine.
Et ponat pedes suos medicus super extremitatem alteram.	And the doctor should place his feet on the other end.
Et stringat bene, donec coartetur Spondilis, et redeat ad locum suum.	And tighten it well, until the spine is compressed, and return to his place.
Deinde si uis, operare cum torno quod inuoluitur cum manu tua: et est, ut figas in terram apud caput infirmi in postremo podii duo ligna, quorum longitudo sit brachii unius: et apud caput eius in postremo podii duo ligna.	Then if you wish, operate with a turning saw that is turned by your hand: and it is, so that you fix in the ground near the head of the patient the two timbers whose length is that of an arm: and near the head of him at the other foot the two timbers.
Et sit longitudo quae est inter omne lignum palmus unus: et iam factum est in omni loco foramen, in quo currit tornum: et firmetur lignum omne in terra multum, ne moueatur omnino.	And the length that is between every piece of timber should be a palm: and there is made in every place a hole, in which the saw runs: and all the wood should be firmly fastened in the ground so that it does not move at all.
Et intromittatur lignum rotundum: et est tornum in quo reuoluitur ligamentum in duobus foraminibus duorum lignorum.	And the round timber is inserted: and there is a saw which turns around in two holes of the two timbers.
Et in extremitate eius est foramen, in quo firmatur lignum, cuius longitudo est palmus cum eo quod reuoluitur: et in duobus lignis aliis est similiter illius.	And at the end thereof is a hole, into which the timber is fastened, whose length is with that by which it turns round: and there is also such a hole in the other two timbers.
Deinde stringe ligamenta quae strinxisti in pectore infirmi torno quod est apud caput eius: et ligamenta quae strinxisti in cruribus eius in torno quod est apud pedes eius.	Then tighten the ligaments that you have tightened inside the patient's body with a turning saw that is at his head: and the ligaments that you have tightened in his legs with a turning saw that is at his feet.
Deinde stet apud omne tornum minister, qui torqueat manum suam cum licinio, cum quo reuoluitur tornum: et medicus aequet Spondilem, secundum quod diximus.	Then let the attendant of every turn stand with his hand turned by a lever, with which he turns the turn: and the doctor is equidistant from Spondile, as we have said.
Haec est forma torni, quae sequitur.	This is the form of the turning table, which follows.
Deinde postquam redit Spondilis, et aequatur locus, tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum exiccatiuum cum albumine oui.	Then, after Spondile has returned and equidistant position is reached, then it should be placed, dried plaster with albumen .
Deinde stuppam.	Then stand.
Postea pone supra emplastrum astellam ex tabula, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, aut circiter eos.	Then place above the plaster a plate from the table, whose width is three fingers wide, or about them.
Et longitudo eius quantitas quae capiat locum Gibbositatis, et super partem Spondilis sanae.	And its length the quantity which takes up the place of vibration, and on the sound side of Spondile.
Deinde ligetur cum ligamento quod diximus.	Then bind with a strap, that we have said.
Et utatur infirmus nutrimento subtili, donec sanetur.	And use delicate food for nourishment until he is healed.
Quod si remaneat quiddam eminentiae in loco in fine sanationis: tunc oportet, ut administrentur medicinae quae mollificant, et leniunt, cum administratione tabulae quam narrauimus tempore longo.	That if anything remains of excellence in the place at the end of recovery: then it should be administered medicine that softens and softens, with the table which we described during a long time.
Et iam administratur in illo lamina plumbi.	And now is administered into that lead layer.
Et quandoque accidit eminentia in postremo Spondilium dorsi: et putatur per eam dislocatio, et est illud os quod iam eminet.	And when it happens that a failure occurs at the end of the back of Spondile: and it should be considered by this dislocation, and it is the opening which it already emits.
Quare non oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei cum hac medicina: fortasse enim accidere faciet mortem.	Why it should not be made to him with this medicine: for perhaps will happen make him die.
Â¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	Of the cure of a dislocated shoulder.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter 32.
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	You should know that the shoulder joints of the arm, and the shoulder joint of the upper arm, do not occur, except by a dislocation; and they do not occur to them what occurs to other joints from a small distance, and because of their position.
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	And a dislocated shoulder can be located according to four parts.
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	Because it is dislocated forward and backward.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	And much more dislocations occur inward; and little dislocations occur forward and backward.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	And the cure of its dislocation inward is: because when you join the cruris a healthy nurse with the sick, it is longer: and his knee joint eminens is more than the healthy, and cannot make the sick double his foot near the hip: and there is a place that follows the hip that is heated, so that the head of the hip has already reached it.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	And his sign is that which happened to him, if it was a dislocation to the outside, that are his opposite accidents from these accidents.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	And the sign of him to whom a dislocation has occurred in front, that is because it spreads his healthy leg according to the complement: however, he does not double himself without pain who is in his knee: and if he tries to walk, he cannot go over that one to the front: and he holds back his urine, and he farts behind him, and when he walks he stumbles over his heel.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	And the sign of him to whom a dislocation has occurred in back, that is because he does not spread his leg, nor can he double himself before he doubles his knee: and it is shorter the other leg: and his knee is soft, and the head of the femur is at the place of it.
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	The reduction of this dislocation is that you should consider then, if the dislocation is old, which has already been healed with the owner of it.
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	Then if you administer the reduction of it, and remains after its own disposition: then is not at all cure.
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	Therefore it should not be supposed that he is perfect.
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	But in that one whose dislocation is recent, and it is from the four kinds of dislocations: then draw near to this, so that you join him, and extend it towards the inside and towards the outside, and move it with your right and left: perhaps it will return, and does not need another cure.
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	But if it does not return in this way, then you should prepare, a strong instrument, and extend his leg from the lower part: or with his hands, or with a ligament that binds above his leg: and another minister extend his hand from above, so that he puts his hands under his toes.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	Then tie it up with a soft ligament over the root of the pelvis, and hold the end of the other ligament.
Et sit extensio eius aut ab anteriori parte inguinis ad partem furculae, aut a posteriori ad partem dorsi.	And sit extension of it or from the anterior part of the groin to the part of the fork, or from the posterior to the part of the back.
Et sit extensio eorum omnium uice una, donec eleuetur infirmus cum corpore suo a terra, et remaneat pendens.	And let all these extend one way by turn, until you lift up the sick man with his body from the ground and let him hang.
Et haec enim species extensionis est species communis specierum quatuor.	For this reason is this kind of extension a common species of the four kinds of extensions.
Si ergo redit dislocatio cum eo quod diximus, est bonum: et si non, tunc necesse est omni speciei illud quod dicam de curatione propria.	But if this return of dislocation with it that I have said, is good, and if not, then it is necessary that all the kind that I say about cure is his own.
In reductione quidem eius propria quando dislocatio est ad interiora, oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super latus suum sanum.	In reduction however of him when dislocation is to the inside, it should be, that the sick man should lie on his sound side.
Deinde ponat ligamentum super radicem coxae, in eo quod est inter caput coxae, et locum qui est sub inguine.	Then put the ligature over the root of the hip, in so much as it is between the head of the hip, and the place which is under the groin.
Deinde extende ligamentum ad sursum a parte inguinis ad altiorem partem corporis, ad partem furculae.	Then extend the ligature to the top from the part of the groin to the higher part of the body, to the part of the fork.
Deinde accipiat minister alius fortis brachia eius, et minuat locum grossum coxae infirmae, et extendat ad exteriora extensione uehementi.	Then take another strong minister his arms, and decrease the big place of the sick hip, and extend to the outer extension strongly.
Iam enim redit ad locum suum.	For he has already returned to his place.
Et haec species est facilioris reliquis speciebus curationis, qua reducitur hoc membrum.	And this kind is easier than the remaining kinds of cure, which this member is reduced.
Si autem excusatur super te, et non obedit tibi ad introitum cum hac specie curationis omnino: tunc oportet, ut ligentur duo pedes infirmi simul cum ligamento forti, leni, super duos calcaneos, et super duo genua: et sit longitudo cuiusque a compare suo quantitatis quatuor digitorum: et sit crus infirmum extensum plus altero quantitate duorum digitorum.	But if he is excused on you, and does not obey to the entrance with this kind of cure at all: then it should be, that two nurses should bind the feet strong, weak, over the two heels, and over the two knees: and let be the length of each from his compeer quantity of four fingers: and let be the width of the sick man extended in two quantities of two fingers.
Deinde suspendatur infirmus super caput ligni, quod sit in domo: et sit longitudo eius a terra quantitas duorum brachiorum.	Then hang up the sick man on the head of the wood, which is in the house: and let be the length of him from the ground quantity of two arms.
Deinde praecipe iuueni forti, ut muniat caput coxae: et suspendatur cum infirmo inuenis alius: et impellat iuuenis alius, muniens coxam cum fortitudine, nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then command a strong youth to support the head of the hip: and hang up with the sick man in another one: and push forward another youth, supporting the hip with strength, because the return is to its place with speed.
In reditione autem eius propria, quando est dislocatio ad exteriora, oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super podium, secundum quod narrauimus in habente gibbositatem.	In reduction therefore of its own, when it is dislocation towards the outside, it is necessary that the sick man lies on his back, according to what we have narrated in having a gibbosity.
Et stringatur ligamentum super crus eius, infirmum proprie, et super pectus eius.	And tie up ligaments over its leg, the sick one himself, and over its chest.
Deinde ponantur duo ligna, unum apud pedes eius, et alterum apud caput ipsius.	Then two pieces of wood are placed, one at his feet, and another at his head.
Deinde ponatur lignum additum in medio podii, fixum bene: super quod inuoluti sint panni humidi, ut non laedat infirmum: et sit lignum inter coxas eius, ut non attrahatur ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then a piece of wood is placed in the middle of the foot, firmly fixed: over which are laid wet cloths so that they do not harm the sick man; and let the wood lie between his thighs, so that it does not attract towards the lower ones by extension.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem suam, et medicus aequet reductionem manu sua.	Then all the ministers extend to their side, and the doctor adjusts the reduction with his hand.
Si ergo obedit ad reuersionem, erit bonum.	If he therefore submits to the reduction, it is good.
Et si non, pone super ipsam tabulam, et preme ipsam, sicut diximus in gibbositate, aequaliter.	And if not, place over it the board, and press it, as we have said in the gibbosity, equally.
Verumtamen oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	However, it is necessary that the sick man lies on his healthy side.
Et quando dislocatio est ad anteriora, tunc oportet, ut extendatur crus infirmi uelociter: et est secundum hanc eandem narrationem super podium: et ponat medicus palmam manus suae dextrae super inguen infirmum.	And when the dislocation is towards the front, then it is necessary that the leg of the sick man be extended quickly: and this same narrative is told on the side: and the doctor places his right hand palm on the hip of the sick man.
Deinde coartet ipsum cum manu altera, et cum illa coartatione pone ipsum extensum ad inferiora ad partem genu.	Then he should hold him with his left hand, and with that holding place he should put him extended towards the lower side of the knee.
Et si dislocatio est ad posteriora: tunc non oportet, ut extendatur infirmus ad inferiora, et sit eleuatus super terram: imo oportet, ut sit positus super rem duram, sicut oportet, ut fit etiam si dislocatur ancha eius ad exteriora, secundum illud quod diximus de accubitu eius super duas anchas: et est super faciem eius, et ligamenta extensa: secundum quod diximus nuper.	And if the dislocation is towards the back: then it is not necessary that the sick man be extended towards the lower side, and that he sit raised on the ground: but it is necessary that he be placed on a hard thing, as also it is necessary for him who dislocates his thigh towards the outside, according to what we said about his lying on two thighs: and let him be face up, and the ligaments extended: according to what we have just said.
Et oportet, ut administretur compressio cum tabula etiam super locum ad quem egreditur iunctura, cum completur reductio secundum quod oportet.	And it is necessary that the compression with the board be administered also to the place from which the joint departs, when the reduction has been completed, according to what is necessary.
Et signum reditionis eius non occultatur tibi: et est, ut extendas duo crura infirmi: et quando uides ea aequalia, et infirmus stringit crus suum, et expandit ipsum absque excusatione: tunc scias, quia iam redit membrum, secundum quod oportet: tunc coniunge duas coxas, et pone emplastrum, et stringe cum imemati, id est, rota: ita, ut non moueatur ancha ad aliquam partium: et adhaereat infirmus quieti tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	And the sign of his recovery shall not be hidden from you: and this is, that you stretch out two legs of the patient; and when you see them equal, and the sick man ties up his leg, and extends himself without excuse: then know that now the limb has returned, as it should: then join the two hips together, and put on a splint, and bind with bandages, that is, rotate: so that its width does not move to any part: and let the sick man rest for three or four days.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et emplastrum, et compara crus cum altero: tunc si uides ea aequalia in statu, tunc scias, quod dislocatio iam firmata est: absolue ergo infirmum ad ambulandum.	Then loosen the ligaments, and the splint, and compare the legs together: then if you see them equal in position, then know that the dislocation is now set: so let the sick person walk.
Et si uides aliquid mollificationis: tunc redi, et emplastra illud, et stringe illud secundum stricturam tuam primam: et dimitte illud etiam tribus diebus.	And if you see any softening: then go back, and put on the splint, and bind it according to your first order: and let him also be at rest for three days.
Deinde solue illud et fac ipsum tardare in ambulatione super utrumque aliquot diebus, donec confortetur bene.	Then loose that, and let the patient walk a little on each side for a few days, until he is well comforted.
Â¶ De dislocationis Genu.	Of the dislocation of the knee joint.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter XXXIII.
Genu dislocatur secundum tres modos.	The knee may be dislocated three ways.
Dislocatur ad exteriora, ad interiora, et ad inferiora, scilicet ad posteriora.	By the outward, inward, and downward way, that is to say, by the rearward.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora.	And it does not dislocate forward.
Et signum dislocationis eius, est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut applicet crus suum ad coxam suam.	And the sign of the dislocation is, that you command the sick person to apply his leg to his hip.
Si autem non adhaeret cum coxa: tunc scias, quod Genu est dislocatum.	If he does not apply it to the hip: then know that the knee joint has been dislocated.
Et restauratio omnium modorum dislocationis eius est, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum, ita ut iam extendat crus suum si potest super illud, et adhaeret dorsum tuum ad faciem eius: et pone pedem eius inter pedes tuos.	And the restoration of all kinds of dislocation is, that you let the sick person sit upright, so that he may extend his leg over it if he can, and rest his back against your chest: and put his foot between your feet.
Deinde adhaerere fac Genu eius cum palmis tuis, et recta eas inter digitos tuos super Genu eius.	Then you should fasten the knee of the patient to your palm, and make them straight with your fingers over the knee joint.
Deinde applica cum palma tua duo latera Genu eius cum fortitudine.	Then apply with your palm two sides of his genitals with strength.
Et minister alius extendat pedem eius, donec redeat Genu ad locum suum.	And another minister extends his foot, until he returns to his place the genu.
Et signum reditionis est, ut adhaereat crus cum coxa in lenitate, non laboriose.	And the sign of the restoration is that it adheres to the thigh with the hip in a gentle way, not laboriously.
Deinde emplastra ipsum, et adhaerere fac crus cum coxa.	Then bind him up, and adhere the thigh to the hip.
Deinde liga ea simul cum uitta tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then bind them together with sutures of twine for days, or four.
Deinde solue ea.	Then dissolve them.
Et non utatur infirmus ambulatione aliquot diebus, donec sanetur.	And do not let the patient walk for a few days, until he is healed.
Si autem recusatur tibi reductio eius, tunc administra extensionem fortem cum ligamentis, quorum praecessit narratio in curatione anchae, donec redeat.	But if you do not get his reduction, then administer a strong extension with ligaments, of which the pre-story in the cure of achilles, until he returns to its place.
Â¶ De curatione dislocationis Calcanei.	The cure of dislocation of the calcaneus.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter IIII.
Calcaneus quandoque remouetur remotione parua, et quandoque dislocatur secundum complementum.	The calcaneus is sometimes reduced with a small movement, and sometimes dislocated after the second compliment.
Et dislocatio eius fit, aut ad interiora, aut ad exteriora.	And the dislocation of it is done, or towards the inside, or towards the outside.
Et signum dislocationis eius est, quod uides Calcaneum inflatum, procedentem ad partem ad quam dislocatur.	And the sign of dislocation of it is that you see the calcaneus swollen, proceeding to the side to which it is dislocated.
Curatio autem remotionis eius, est facilis reditionis: et est, ut extendatur cum facilitate cum manibus, et aequetur, donec redeat.	But the cure of the reduction of it is easy; and is, that he be extended with ease with hands, and be smoothed out, until it returns to its place.
In curatione autem eius quando dislocatur secundum complementum, oportet, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum: et teneat ipsum minister fortis ualde a posteriori parte dorsi eius, in medio ipsius.	In the cure of him when it is dislocated after the second compliment, you should make the patient sit straight up: and hold him by a strong minister strongly from the back part of his waist, in the middle of it.
Deinde tene tu cum manu tua dextra pedem eius a superiori parte eius, et cum manu tua sinistra ab inferiori parte pedis eius loco cauillae.	Then hold with your right hand your foot from the upper part of it, and with your left hand from the lower part of the foot where the heel is.
Deinde trahe pedem ad tecum manu tua dextra.	Then pull the foot towards you with your right hand.
Deinde cum sinistra duabus uicibus.	Then with two fingers of your left hand.
Deinde extende cum sinistra, et impelle pectus pedis cum dextra uersus crus absque labore.	Then extend with ease, and push the chest of the foot towards the hip without labor.
Fac illud bis, sicut narrauimus.	Do this twice, as we have narrated it.
Deinde impelle pectus pedis ad crus in uice tertia, et tu trahis cauillam.	Then press the chest of the foot to the leg in the third place, and you tear the joint.
Si ergo redit in uice una, aut in duabus secundum hunc modum, et uides pedem aequatum, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera operationem super ipsum: quoniam ipse redit.	If then he returns in one juice, or in two the second way, and you see the foot even, it is good: and if not, then repeat the operation on himself: for he will return again.
Si autem prohibetur tibi reductio eius cum eo quod narrauimus: tunc fac iacere infirmum super dorsum suum super terram, et fige paxillum in terra firmatum ualde, ut cadat inter coxas eius: et tu iam inuoluisti super ipsum pannum, ut non laedat infirmum.	If however it is forbidden to you the reduction with him that we have described: then make him lie on his back on the ground, and fasten the splint firmly on the ground so that it falls between his thighs: and you have already wound the cloth around him so that it does not hurt the sick.
Deinde accipiat minister coxam eius: postea extendat minister alter pedem, aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento quod liget super collum pedis.	Then let the servant take the foot of him: then the other servant extends the leg, or with his hands, or with a bandage that binds over the neck of the foot.
Deinde extendat omnis minister contra extensionem comparis sui: et paxillus sit stans inter duas coxas infirmi retinens eum, ut non attrahatur corpus eius ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then let all the servants extend against the extension of their own: and the splint be standing between the two thighs of the nurse while she holds it, so that his body is not pulled towards the lower part by the extension.
Deinde aequet medicus dislocationem manibus suis, et minister alter teneat crus sanum ad inferiora.	Then let the doctor adjust the dislocation with his hands, and the other servant hold the leg healthy from below.
Nam dislocatio redit cum uelocitate.	For the dislocation returns with velocity.
Quando ergo redit dislocatio, et declaratur tibi sanitas reditionis eius: tunc pone emplastrum et stuppam, et stringe ipsam cum ligamentis firmiter, et liga pedem cum ligamento ad crus.	When however the dislocation returns, and it is declared to you that the return of it is healthy: then put on a splint and padding, and tighten it with bandages firmly, and tie the foot to the leg with a bandage.
Et oportet, ut caueas uel timeas de neruis, qui sunt supra calcaneum posterius, ut non sit ligamentum super eos uehemens, et laedat eos.	And it is necessary that you should beware and fear the nerves that are above the heel at the back, so that the bandage does not press on them painfully, and hurts them.
Deinde dimitte ipsum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then let go of him after two days, or three.
Quod si mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum: deinde solue ipsum in die tertio, aut quarto: et prohibe infirmum ab ambulatione quadraginta diebus.	If however the bandage becomes soft, tighten him up: then let go of him in a third or fourth day: and forbid the sick one from walking for forty days.
Si uero conatur ambulare ante illud spacium, non fit securitas quin dissoluatur super ipsum dislocatio, et corrumpatur, et non recipiat post illud curationem.	If however he tries to walk before that space, there is no security except that the dislocation be dissolved on him, and it is corrupted, and does not receive after that cure.
Quod si accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc oportet, ut administres in sedatione eius illud, in quo praecessit narratio nostra in alio loco ex curatione, et embrocationem, donec remoueatur.	If it happens that he has a hot apostema: then you should give him sedatives and embrocations until it goes away.
Â¶ De dislocatione Digitorum pedis, et cura.	On the dislocation of fingers of the foot, and their treatment.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 25. On the dislocation of fingers of the foot
Oportet, ut aequetur quod dislocatur ex eis cum extensione pauca absque labore: et illud quidem non est difficile, imo est facile.	It should be treated with little extension without effort; and this is not difficult, indeed it is easy.
Si autem dislocatio est in quibusdam nodis dorsi pedis: tunc oportet, ut faciat sedere infirmus pedem suum super locum aequalem terrae, aut super tabulam: et est stans sicut ambulans.	If the dislocation is in the toes of the back of the foot: then he should make the injured foot stand on an equal place of the ground, or on a board: and it is as steady as when walking.
Deinde tu sta, et pone pedem tuum super illud quod eminet ex illis iuncturis.	Then you shall stand, and put your foot upon that which protrudes from them, the joint.
Deinde calca illud cum pede tuo cum uirtute, donec redeat, et uideas ipsum iam aequatum, et non appareat in loco eminentia.	Then step on it with your foot with force, until it turns, and does not appear to be out of place, and does not project in the spot.
Deinde pone sub uentre pedis eius tabulam quae capiat pedem totum, cui sint duo capita.	Then put under his foot a board which takes all the foot, which has two heads.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti tribus diebus.	Then tighten it with strings by tying for three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et fac quiescere eum ab ambulatione diebus multis, donec stringatur et securetur a reductione.	Then solve it, and allow it to rest from walking for several days, until it is tightened and made secure by reduction.
Â¶ De speciebus dislocationis cum uulnere uel fractura.	On the species of dislocation with a sprain or fracture.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36. On the species of dislocation with a sp
Quando accidit aliquid ex illo, et conaris curationem eius, et ipsius restaurationem, multotiens succedit mors: et propter illud non oportet, ut praesumat super curationem eius, quod est huiusmodi, nisi qui est prudens in arte longi usus, misericors, pius, tardus, non audax, neque praesumptuosus: et ut utatur in incaeptionce medicinis quae sedant apostemata calida tantum: et dimittat infirmum diuino iudicio.	When something of this kind has happened, and he is inclined to the care of it, and to its restoration; death often succeeds many times, and therefore it is not necessary to be hasty in his treatment, which is of this kind, unless he is prudent in the art, compassionate, merciful, slow, not brave, nor presumptuous: and that he uses in the beginning of medicines which sedate hot poultices only: and lets the sick man rest by divine judgment.
Nisi uideas, aut speras salutem a perditione cum lenitate aegritudinis, et in quo apparet quiddam spei.	Except you hope for salvation from destruction with gentleness of sickness, and in which there appears some hope.
Conare ergo reductionem eius statim in principio rei, antequam accidat apostema calidum.	Therefore, he must begin the reduction immediately at the start of the affair, before the appearance of the apoplexy [i.e., fever].
Si ergo redit membrum, secundum quod uolumus, tunc administra regimen quod sedat apostema: et cura uulnus cum eo quod conuenit ei ex unguentis desiccatiuis.	If then the limb returns [to health], according to what we have ordered, then administer the treatment that calms down the apoplexy: and care for the wound with the same thing that suits him when it comes out of the dried ointment.
Quod si dislocatio est cum fractura, et accidunt in osse satagiae separatae, tunc conare ablationem earum, et fac in illo quod diximus in aegritudinibus simplicibus ex eo quod praecessit in locis earum.	That if the dislocation is with a fracture and happen in the bone of the separated places, then try to remove them, and do in it what we said in the simple illnesses from because it preceded in those places.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, et custodi teipsum ab introitu in uiam timoris: secundum quod praecessit praedicatio mea tibi.	And be careful according to your ability, and guard yourself from the entrance into a path of fear: according to my prediction for you.
Nam illud est melius tibi apud Creatorem tuum, et magis permanens ad gloriam tuam, et magis saluum tuo corpori apud illos in tuo tempore.	For that is better for you with your Creator, and more enduring to your glory, and more safe to your body there with them at that time.
